text: A conservative social media influencer, Isabella DeLuca, has been arrested on charges related to her involvement in the Jan. 6, 2021, riot at the U.S. Capitol, including an accusation that she helped to steal a table that was used to assault officers, according to court documents.

An engine fire, a tire lost shortly after takeoff and a plane veering off the runway: United Airlines has had eight incidents in two weeks. While no one was injured, most of the mishaps required emergency landings or diversions. Here’s what travelers should know.

Donald Trump accused Jewish voters of hating their religion and Israel if they vote for Democrats, reviving and escalating antisemitic claims he made as president that were widely criticized. His comments, which he made on a conservative radio program, drew outrage from Jewish Democrats.

A second man has been charged in connection with the 2005 theft of a pair of ruby slippers worn by Judy Garland in “The Wizard of Oz,” according to the authorities, who said that he had threatened to a release a sex tape of a woman if she told the authorities about the theft.

Of all the classroom visits the author Tommy Orange has made since “There There” came out in 2018, the one at a Bronx high school earlier this month was “the most intense connection I’ve ever experienced.”
The signature cherry blossoms in Washington, D.C., have arrived early after a warm winter, matching the second-earliest peak bloom in more than a century of record-keeping.

Donald Trump’s lawyers said that he faces “insurmountable difficulties” to secure a roughly half-billion dollar bond in his civil fraud case in New York. The state could seek to freeze some of his bank accounts and seize some of his properties.

President Vladimir Putin said he would not back down in Russia’s war against Ukraine to a crowd of thousands in Moscow on Monday, a day after declaring victory in a performative election that prompted comparisons to other authoritarian dictatorships.

A majority of U.S. Supreme Court justices seemed likely to side with arguments by the NRA on Monday that a New York official violated the First Amendment by encouraging entities to break ties with the group after the Parkland mass shooting.

In a lawsuit filed Monday, a former police colleague of Mayor Eric Adams said that he demanded oral sex in exchange for career help in 1993 and sexually assaulted her when she refused. Adams has repeatedly denied assaulting the woman.
Not one of the 13 works stolen during the Gardner Museum Heist of 1990, the largest art theft in history, has surfaced. Here are five oddities of the case that still draw interest.

Donald Trump is scheduled to go on trial in several weeks in a case in which he’s accused of covering up a 2016 payment to Stormy Daniels. “Stormy,” a new documentary on Peacock, recounts the legal saga from her perspective. Read our review.
The Department of Homeland Security will be the first federal agency to roll out a comprehensive plan to incorporate generative AI models across a wide range of divisions.

Famine is projected in northern Gaza, according to a new report from a global authority on food security set up by UN agencies and international relief groups. It has classified a famine only twice before: in Somalia in 2011 and in South Sudan in 2017. nyti.ms/49VNXeJ

Shakira said she “transformed pain into productivity” with “Las Mujeres Ya No Lloran,” her first album in seven years. Our critic spoke with the Colombian superstar about the album from her home in Miami.

At least eight people were killed by Pakistani airstrikes launched into Afghanistan on Monday morning, according to Taliban officials, escalating tensions between two countries that have clashed over the recent rise in militant violence on Pakistan’s soil.
Breaking News: Gambian lawmakers voted to revoke a ban on female genital cutting. If the vote is sustained, Gambia would be the first to undo such protections for millions of girls. nyti.ms/3wTy9dU
Breaking News: Missouri and Louisiana argued that federal efforts to limit misinformation on social media platforms were censorship. The Supreme Court seemed to disagree.

The Israeli military said that it was in the process of conducting a raid of Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital, claiming that senior Hamas officials had regrouped there. Hamas has denied using the complex as a command center, but U.S. spy agencies believe it has.

Breaking News: Donald Trump’s lawyers said that he has failed to secure a $454 million bond for a civil fraud case in New York, despite approaching 30 companies for help, raising the prospect that Trump might now face a financial crisis.

Justice Stephen Breyer retired in 2022, somewhat reluctantly. In a new book, the justice discussed the decline of trust in the Supreme Court and the Dobbs decision, which he dissented, that eliminated the constitutional right to abortion.

The Supreme Court is hearing arguments on whether the Biden administration violated the First Amendment in its efforts to combat misinformation on social media. It’s the latest in a series of cases assessing the boundaries of free speech in the digital age.
Listen to “The Headlines,” which brings you the biggest stories of the day from the New York Times reporters who are covering them, all in about five minutes.
Breaking News from @@2650: The Premier League handed Nottingham Forest a four-point deduction for breaching its financial rules, dropping the club to 18th in the league.
Vladimir Putin is set to assume his fifth term as president of Russia after a predetermined vote, despite quiet protests at polling stations.

While there is little doubt about the outcome of Russia's presidential election, there is concern among voters that an emboldened President Vladimir Putin may use a win to declare another mobilization for soldiers to fight in Ukraine.
In the Trump era, a surprising number of evangelicals are rejecting modesty and turning toward the risqué.

Russian voters formed long lines outside polling stations in major cities during the presidential election on Sunday.

Opposition leaders said showing solidarity by mere presence was more important than what the voters chose to do with their ballots, because the election lacked real choice.

A gang assault on Haiti’s capital has left an already weak health care system in tatters. Many hospitals have been looted by gangs or abandoned by their staffs amid the violence. Some are open, but too dangerous for people in need of care to reach.

In a speech in Ohio on Saturday, Donald Trump doubled down on a doomsday vision of the United States, saying if he isn't elected "it’s going to be a blood bath" and calling some migrants "not people" and "animals."

Surprise attacks by Russians who have turned against the government of their country’s president, Vladimir Putin, are meant to undermine the sense of stability in Russia and divert the country’s military resources from Ukraine.
Donald Trump is facing converging financial crunches as he and the Republican Party confront a shortfall against President Biden and the Democrats. Here's what he has been doing to raise cash.
With just days to go before the election, the three-way Republican Senate primary in Ohio is still a contentious fight, fueling concerns about Donald Trump’s favored candidate, Bernie Moreno.

The war in Ukraine. Hamas’s attack on Israel. Inflation. Donald Trump has insisted that none would have occurred if he had remained in office after 2020.

Here’s a closer look at those claims.

Russia is holding a presidential vote in the occupied regions of Ukraine to try to legitimize its rule there, expose dissenters and present a veneer of democracy. Poll workers are soliciting votes that are set to give Vladimir Putin his fifth term as president and another six years in office.
Here are candid shots from the audience at Sunday night’s Oscars ceremony, where our photographer captured moments viewers may not have caught otherwise. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/14/m...
Joe Camp, a pioneering filmmaker who created the groundbreaking “Benji” franchise, a live-action film series from a dog’s perspective, died on Friday. He was 84.

The silent film “The Callahans and the Murphys” was pulled after an uproar over stereotyping. Our journalist then fell into a rabbit hole about “lost” movies, an unlikely box office star and a secure facility where national memories are stored.

The National Association of Realtors has agreed to settle a series of lawsuits by paying $418 million in damages. It also agreed to rewrite rules that have long been central to the U.S. housing industry. 

Here’s how things stand to change, pending court approval. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/15/r...
Breaking News: A New York judge delayed Donald Trump’s Manhattan criminal trial until at least mid-April, postponing the only one of Trump’s four criminal cases that appeared set to begin.

Senator Katie Britt, who delivered a jarring State of the Union response from an oddly empty kitchen, is not the first freshman Republican senator from the South to see her introductory event veer off the rails, our chief Washington correspondent writes.

Migrant adults will not be allowed to stay in New York City shelters for more than 30 days, with certain exceptions for families with children, under a new legal agreement to change a policy that the city provide shelter to homeless people who seek it.

Nathan Wade, the lead prosecutor in the Trump election interference case in Georgia, resigned from the role after a judge’s ruling about his relationship with Fani Willis, the Fulton County DA. Here are takeaways from ruling.
Read Nathan Wade’s resignation letter.

Nathan Wade, the lead prosecutor in the Georgia election interference case, will quit after a judge’s ruling about his relationship with Fani Willis, the Fulton County DA. Willis will now be able to pursue the case against Donald Trump and his allies.

President Biden’s counsel told Speaker Mike Johnson that it was “obviously time to move on” from House Republicans’ effort to impeach the president, after their monthslong inquiry failed to turn up promised evidence of high crimes and misdemeanors.
Breaking News: Jared Kushner is pursuing real estate deals in Albania and Serbia as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, runs for president.

President Biden on Friday praised Senator Chuck Schumer’s address lashing out at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. Biden called it “a good speech” without explicitly endorsing its specific criticisms or its call for new elections to replace the Israeli leader.

Breaking News: Federal prosecutors asked that Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, receive a 40- to 50-year sentence for his conviction on fraud charges. He faces a maximum possible penalty of 110 years.

Breaking News: The subway rider who shot a man he had been fighting on a moving A train in the head appears to have acted in self-defense and is unlikely to be criminally charged for now, the Brooklyn DA said.

Here is a timeline of when the relationship between Fani Willis, the Fulton County DA leading the Georgia election interference case, and Nathan Wade, the lawyer she hired to help manage the prosecution, came to light — and how defense lawyers used it to attack the prosecutors.

What happens next with TikTok? The legislative process is still in its early stages after the House passed a bill this week that would force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell its app or be banned in the U.S. Here’s what to expect.
The Russian presidential election, which began Friday and lasts through Sunday, features the trappings of a horse race but is more of a predetermined, Soviet-style referendum. Here's what to know.

Breaking News: Al Shabab terrorists on Thursday breached a heavily fortified hotel in Somalia’s capital, near the country's presidential palace, killing three soldiers in a 12-hour siege before dying in a gunfight.

Senator Chuck Schumer’s harsh critique of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his government revealed the widening gap between the U.S. and Israel, analysts said on Friday. “We’ve never seen anything like this,” said a retired Israeli diplomat.

Several families, including that of the man who recorded a video of officers using a stun gun on a Venezuelan migrant holding a toddler at a shelter in Queens, were abruptly transferred to other New York City-run shelters with little explanation.

Donald Trump is facing multiple legal challenges related to his business and political activities, with the cases expected to play out over the coming months. Here's a guide to the major criminal cases involving the former president.

The U.S. and the other G7 leaders warned Iran on Friday not to provide ballistic missiles to Russia and threatened to retaliate if it does by cutting off Iranian air travel to Europe, among other measures.

The sudden plunge of a Latam Airlines Boeing 787 Dreamliner bound for Auckland, New Zealand, might have been caused by a flight attendant hitting a switch on a cockpit seat. About 50 passengers were treated for injuries after the incident on Monday.

A humanitarian aid ship arrived on Friday in Gaza for the first time since the start of the war, part of a new maritime operation to bring more aid to hungry Palestinians. It is also the first vessel authorized to deliver aid to Gaza since 2005, according to the EU.

An Atlanta judge on Friday ruled that Fani Willis, the Fulton County DA, could continue leading the prosecution of Donald Trump and his allies in Georgia, but only if her former romantic partner, Nathan Wade, withdraws from the case. Here's what to know.
Breaking News: A man was shot in the head and critically wounded on a Brooklyn subway car after threatening a passenger with a gun. Videos show how the fight unfolded.
Trevor Penny was magnet fishing in an English waterway near Oxford when he pulled out a rusty sword. Experts say it’s a Viking sword that is probably more than 1,000 years old.

At least 16 people were killed and 55 others injured by a Russian missile attack on Odesa, Ukrainian authorities said on Friday, the latest in a series of deadly air assaults on the southern Ukrainian port city.

Fani Willis, the Fulton County DA leading the Georgia election interference case, faces a series of inquiries that could perpetuate questions about her character and uncertainty around Donald Trump's trial for months to come.

Senator Bernie Sanders proposed legislation to reduce the standard workweek in the U.S. from 40 hours to 32, without a reduction in pay. The law, if passed, would lower the threshold at which workers would be eligible to receive overtime pay. nyti.ms/3TzFHLM
A bill to force TikTok’s sale in the U.S. has been criticized by China’s leaders but has not triggered a major public response or prompted retaliatory threats against American companies. Here’s why.

The romance between Fani Willis and the lead prosecutor she hired to oversee the Georgia Trump case created an “appearance of impropriety,” the judge said, ruling that the prosecution can’t proceed unless he leaves or she steps aside. Read the decision.

Russians go to the polls today in the first presidential election since President Vladimir Putin ordered his forces to invade Ukraine two years ago. Our Moscow-based reporter traveled around the country to gauge voter sentiment. Listen to “The Daily.”

The allegations of a romance between Fani Willis, the Fulton County DA, and Nathan Wade first emerged in a filing by a lawyer for one of Donald Trump’s co-defendants in Georgia. Here's what we know about the prosecutors' relationship.
Breaking News: Home sellers in the U.S. would no longer be forced to pay up to 6% commission to agents under a settlement that experts say will drive down prices. nyti.ms/3veFZhU
Breaking News: A judge said that Fani Willis could remain on Donald Trump’s election interference case in Georgia, if the lawyer she hired to run it withdrew. nyti.ms/3ThN0GK

The World Bank’s internal watchdog on Thursday criticized the organization’s handling and oversight of its investment in a chain of Kenyan schools that were subject to an internal investigation after allegations that students were abused.

Breaking News: The father of the teenager who carried out Michigan’s deadliest school shooting was convicted of involuntary manslaughter in the 2021 attack. His wife was convicted last month on the same charges. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/14/u...

We often ask ourselves: How many steps are enough? But focusing purely on the number of steps misses the whole picture. Researchers say that after a certain point, what kind of steps you’re taking is just as important as the amount.

Here are a few ways to make the most of your daily walk.

Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, debuted an Instagram account on Thursday that announced a new venture, American Riviera Orchard. Meghan released a mysterious 15-second video, but little is known about what appears to be a kitchen and lifestyle brand. A trademark application offers some clues.

The actor Pierce Brosnan pleaded guilty on Thursday to hiking in a restricted thermal area of Yellowstone National Park in November, court records show. As part of a plea deal, he was ordered to pay a fine of $500 and make a $1,000 donation to Yellowstone Forever, a nonprofit partner of the park.

About 50 migrants died after their small boat deflated during an attempt to cross the central Mediterranean Sea, a European humanitarian aid group said on Thursday. Survivors, who departed from Libya, said they had been adrift for four days when they were found.
A winter storm pummeled Colorado with heavy snow and gusty winds overnight Wednesday into Thursday, forcing highway shutdowns and power outages, and creating travel headaches, the authorities said.

A man was shot in the head at the Hoyt-Schermerhorn subway station in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday evening, the authorities said. The victim was transported to a nearby hospital with serious injuries.
Breaking News: A federal judge rejected one of Donald Trump’s requests to dismiss his case related to the mishandling of classified documents.

New York City's St. Patrick’s Day Parade is on Saturday. It's the 263rd iteration of one of the world’s longest-running parades.

Here's what to know about this year's festivities.

A Manhattan judge refused on Thursday to dismiss bribery and other charges against Senator Robert Menendez on the grounds that they violate constitutional protections afforded to members of Congress. Menendez could file an appeal of the ruling.

“For some people, Pi Day is an occasion to marvel at circles, long revered as symbols of perfection, reincarnation and the cycles of nature. But it is the domestication of infinity that we really should be celebrating.” 🥧

Vice President Kamala Harris called the flood of laws restricting abortion access as a “health care crisis” as she visited abortion providers and staff on Thursday in Minnesota. It's believed to be the first visit by a vice president to an abortion clinic.

Some California counties are preparing to investigate fentanyl deaths as homicides, a big shift for some in their approach to drug-related crimes. Critics call the prosecution of street dealers a misguided return to the aggressive approaches of the 1990s.
Breaking News: The Manhattan prosecutors who charged Donald Trump are seeking a delay of his criminal trial less than two weeks before it was set to begin.

“People literally have no other safe place to go.”

More than one million Palestinians have fled to Rafah in southern Gaza, hoping to escape the war. As they hunt for food and shelter, a potential Israeli invasion has added to their fears.
Breaking News: Esa-Pekka Salonen, the music director of the San Francisco Symphony, said he would step down when his contract expires next year, citing differences with the orchestra’s board.

The widow of the man who was shot and killed while trying to break up a fight on a New York subway says photos of his body were shared online. The MTA is conducting an internal investigation to determine if employees took and shared the graphic images.
SpaceX’s powerful Starship rocket completed most of its latest test flight but didn’t survive re-entering Earth’s atmosphere. Here are the latest updates. nyti.ms/492OMl2
Breaking News: Senator Chuck Schumer criticized Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and called for new leadership in Israel, five months into the war in Gaza.

Nex Benedict, a 16-year-old nonbinary student in Oklahoma who died a day after a physical altercation in a high school girls’ bathroom, died as a result of suicide, according to an autopsy report released on Wednesday.

Israel’s bombing campaign has devastated telecommunications infrastructure in Gaza, largely preventing Palestinians from calling for help and communicating with family abroad. Engineers and technicians have risked their lives to reinstate service.
Read our investigation here.

Michigan will no longer allow guns marked for destruction to be sold online as parts. The weapons will now be crushed and melted down “in their entirety” at a scrap metal site, the police said on Tuesday. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/13/u...

“The pandemic is something I carry with me, consciously, all the time.”

Covid was declared a national emergency on March 13, 2020. For many Americans, the pandemic’s effects are still a prominent part of their daily lives.

Olivia Munn was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer last year and soon after had a double mastectomy as part of her treatment, the actress said on Wednesday. Munn said she was given the diagnosis two months after negative results on a test that checked for 90 cancer genes.

Breaking News: Don Lemon’s agreement for a new talk show on X, the social media platform formerly known as Twitter, was canceled days before his show was set to debut. The former news anchor said the deal blew up after he interviewed Elon Musk.
In the Magazine, Nikole Hannah-Jones writes about how the fall of affirmative action is part of a 50-year campaign to roll back racial progress. nyti.ms/3IBMgr1

Neil Young will return his music to Spotify, two years after withdrawing it in protest over the podcast host Joe Rogan’s shows about Covid-19, the veteran rock musician announced on his website Tuesday.

“It’s expectation setting. If I don’t get to it, it’s not personal. I’m just busy.” Smartphones never seem to stop vibrating, pinging and lighting up in an incessant quest for our attention. That’s where “Do Not Disturb” mode comes in.
Reddit is poised to reach the stock market in one of the first tech initial public offerings of the year. Here's how the 19-year-old company got to this point.

The House on Wednesday passed a bill with broad bipartisan support that would force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell the app or be banned in the U.S. The action came despite TikTok’s efforts to mobilize its 170 million U.S. users against the measure. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/13/t...

Breaking News: A judge quashed six of the 41 charges against Donald Trump and his allies in the Georgia election interference case, including one related to a call that Trump made to pressure Georgia’s secretary of state in early January 2021.
Breaking News: The House passed a bill with broad bipartisan support that would force TikTok’s Chinese owner to sell the app or face a ban in the U.S.

Nebraska legislators passed a bill last month to allow local governments to establish needle exchanges. Gov. Jim Pillen then vetoed the bill, and on Tuesday, state lawmakers narrowly sustained his veto.

A Boeing whistle-blower was found dead on Saturday with what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, local officials said. A former quality manager for the company, John Barnett had been in Charleston, South Carolina, for a deposition in a lawsuit in which he accused Boeing of retaliation.

Breaking News: The NFL star Aaron Rodgers and Jesse Ventura, the former Minnesota governor, top the running mate list of the longshot candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

Kennedy said he had been speaking with Rodgers “pretty continuously” for the past month.
Breaking News: The Alaska Airlines plane that lost a door panel midflight had been scheduled for maintenance that same day to address a potential problem.
Unlike for Ukrainian men, there is no mandatory draft for women. But thousands of women have enlisted, and they are increasingly volunteering for combat roles. nyti.ms/3vc9dhl
A decade after Gabriel García Márquez’s death, the publication of “Until August” adds a surprising twist to his legacy. Here’s a look at his expansive catalog.

Over the years, Walmart — the largest private employer in the U.S. — has been accused of being more focused on the bottom line than its 1.6 million workers. The company is now training its managers to prioritize their staff’s physical and mental health.

Gabriel García Márquez’s last novel, “Until August,” written as the Colombian author’s memory began declining, is out now. “It would be hard to imagine a more unsatisfying goodbye,” Michael Greenberg writes. Read our review.
Breaking News: With Ukraine war aid stalled in Congress, the White House announced a stopgap plan to provide up to $300 million in weapons.

Ariana Grande’s latest album takes its name from Michel Gondry’s movie about the impossible fantasy of purging a past relationship from memory. Read our 2004 film review for “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind.” nyti.ms/4acTj5l

A federal judge dismissed a defamation lawsuit against Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, on Tuesday. Meghan’s half sister had accused her of making “disparaging, hurtful and false” statements in an interview with Oprah Winfrey and in a Netflix documentary series.

When pictures started rolling in of Major League Baseball players in their new uniforms for the 2024 season, one thing was clear: the redesigned pants were see-through. The transparency of the pants quickly became an online sensation. nyti.ms/3VfoBUN
Four years after the pandemic began, U.S. employers have reached a new hybrid-work status quo. Here’s a look at who still works from home: nyti.ms/4a9uHKF

A Republican group dedicated to opposing Donald Trump is planning to spend $50 million on an advertising campaign that features videos of his former supporters who say they can no longer back him in 2024.

The companies who own dating apps like Tinder and Bumble have lost more than $40 billion in market value since 2021. Both companies are facing one critical obstacle: Not enough young people are willing to pay for subscriptions.
Breaking News: Video shows a New York City police officer using a stun gun on a migrant man holding his 1-year-old son.
Breaking News: Kenya paused its plans to send a police force to Haiti to combat gang violence, citing the Haitian prime minister’s intent to step down.
Researchers are documenting deathbed visions, a phenomenon that seems to help the dying and those they leave behind.

Airbnb is banning the use of all indoor security cameras in its listings worldwide, the company said, in an update to its policy allowing the devices to be installed in common areas like hallways and living rooms. It comes after the widespread use of indoor cameras has raised privacy concerns.

Andrew Tate, an influencer known for his misogynistic views, is facing criminal accusations over sexual misconduct, including human trafficking, in two separate cases. He and his brother were detained in Romania on Monday, their spokesman said. Here's what to know.

To combat drug use, Oregon voted in 2020 to decriminalize the possession of small amounts of hard drugs including fentanyl, heroin and methamphetamine. Lawmakers are about to reverse course.

Listen to today’s episode of The Daily.
Senator Bernie Sanders and seven Democrats urged President Biden on Monday to stop providing offensive weapons to Israel until it lifts restrictions on U.S.-backed humanitarian aid going into Gaza.

The special counsel who investigated President Biden's handling of sensitive government documents, Robert Hur, is testifying before the House Judiciary Committee. He will likely face questions about his justifications for not charging the president and his notes about Biden’s memory. 

Watch live:

Even as the 96th Academy Awards indulged in the usual jokes, there were also references to the 2023 strikes and current wars. Our chief film critic and movie critic discuss the show, the awards and the snubs.

A Mother’s Day photo released by Kensington Palace of the the Princess of Wales and her children was meant to douse speculation about her health and whereabouts. It did the opposite — and threatened to undermine trust in the royal family.

"I’m enjoying the process of getting older," Pamela Anderson, 56, told us. "The things that are happening to my face — a little elasticity is leaving — I’m finding humor in that." She added: "I feel sexier now that I have some secrets and some mystery."

Drivers of cars by General Motors, Kia, Subaru and Mitsubishi may not realize that their driving data — like when they sped or braked too hard — is being shared with insurance companies. Numerous people have complained about spiking premiums as a result. nyti.ms/3wHDftF

Donald Trump’s driver on Jan. 6 confirmed that Trump demanded to go to the Capitol but said “I did not see him reach” for the steering wheel, contradicting the most hotly disputed elements of testimony given to the House committee by a White House aide.

A meteor that fell from space and landed in the Pacific Ocean in 2014 was not an alien artifact, as some scientists had posited. The seismic data from the fireball was likely just a normal human truck driving past a seismometer, a recent study suggests.

Graffiti with swastikas, racist language and a graphic threat of a school shooting was found on a boys’ bathroom stall at Beacon High School in Manhattan last week. The police said the vandalism was being investigated as a potential hate crime.
Democrats are hopeful that President Biden can wrench North Carolina away from Donald Trump in November, but they’re less confident that Biden can hold on to Georgia. Here's why.

E. Jean Carroll will not contest Donald Trump’s $91.6 million bond, but her lawyer, Roberta Kaplan, said she had been tracking Trump’s campaign trail remarks and is considering filing yet another defamation lawsuit against him.

A judge is preparing to issue a high-stakes decision in the Georgia case against Donald Trump: whether to disqualify Fani Willis, the prosecutor leading the case, on the grounds that her romance with a subordinate created a conflict of interest.
Here is where you can stream “Oppenheimer,” “Poor Things” and more 2024 Oscar winners.

Senator Robert Menendez was arraigned for the third time in six months, this time on new criminal charges filed as part of an expansive federal bribery investigation. The new charges come less than two months before the scheduled start of the trial, May 6.
People with PCOS were told for years that cutting calories would ease their symptoms. But dieting may not help at all, research suggests.

“Even without Ramadan, we are fasting,” said a 42-year-old mother of four in Jabaliya. The war in Gaza has erased how Palestinians used to live and observe the holy month of Ramadan. Follow our live coverage: nyti.ms/3uUPH9a

Donald Trump offered a rambling and confusing explanation of why he had reversed himself on whether the U.S. should ban TikTok, telling CNBC that a ban would make young people “go crazy” and could benefit Facebook, which he called an “enemy of the people.”

We knew Ryan Gosling was going to perform “I’m Just Ken,” from “Barbie.” And that “Oppenheimer” was a front-runner. Still, we weren’t prepared for just how much the ceremony would get a boost from those twin blockbusters.

Here are the highlights from the 2024 Oscars.

The University of Texas at Austin will again require standardized tests for admissions, becoming the latest university to reinstate requirements for SAT or ACT scores that were abandoned during the pandemic.

"Isn't it past your jail time?"

Jimmy Kimmel used some of his final stage time hosting the Oscars on Sunday to read a post published on Truth Social by Donald Trump. And yes, Trump really had posted it. nyti.ms/3IuOwjV

President Biden’s 2025 budget proposal includes about $3 trillion in deficit reduction over a decade, largely from raising taxes on the rich and corporations. It stands almost no chance of becoming law this year, given that Republicans control the House.

At the Oscars, Jimmy Kimmel read a post that Donald Trump published on social media about his performance as the show's host. Then Kimmel jabbed back, expressing surprise that Trump had stayed up to watch the telecast: "Isn't it past your jail time?"

The Ukrainian director Mstyslav Chernov used his acceptance speech for “20 Days in Mariupol,” which won the Oscar for best documentary feature on Sunday, to give an emotional denunciation of the continued invasion of his country by Russian forces.

Godzilla is one of cinema’s longest running characters. But the prehistoric monster had never been to the Oscars until now. “Godzilla Minus One,” the 37th film in the franchise, finally broke through, winning for best visual effects.

"An uber-fit naked man pretending to be frantic as he exposed himself at the Oscars was more than funny, it was a mini-meditation on the still-enormous gender gap at fashion’s highest level,” Rhonda Garelick writes about John Cena’s skit. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/10/s...

The in memoriam segment at the Academy Awards opened with a clip of Aleksei Navalny from “Navalny,” the Oscar-winning 2022 documentary about the Russian opposition leader who died last month in a Russian prison.

Al Pacino put a room full of stars a little bit on edge to close out the 96th Academy Awards. Rather than listing all 10 nominees while presenting the best picture Oscar, or offering a conventional “And the Oscar goes to,” Pacino simply said “Here it comes” before slowly opening the envelope.

“Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s hit drama about the man who helped create the atomic bomb, won best picture. That victory capped a huge night for the film, which won seven Oscars total. www.nytimes.com/live/2024/03...

Emma Stone won the Oscar for best actress for her performance as Bella Baxter in “Poor Things.” The victory is Stone’s second for best actress: she won for her role in the 2016 musical “La La Land.” www.nytimes.com/2024/03/10/m...

Christopher Nolan won the Oscar for best director for “Oppenheimer.” This is his first directing Oscar. Before this year, Nolan had been nominated for directing only once, for the 2017 film “Dunkirk.” www.nytimes.com/live/2024/03...

Cillian Murphy won the Oscar for best actor for his portrayal in “Oppenheimer” of the physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer, who developed the atomic bomb. This is Murphy’s first Oscar win and his first nomination. www.nytimes.com/live/2024/03...

In one of the most anticipated moments of Oscar night, Ryan Gosling took the stage to perform “I’m Just Ken,” the nominated song from “Barbie” by Mark Ronson and Andrew Wyatt. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/10/m...

Messi, the Border collie who plays Snoop in the French courtroom thriller “Anatomy of a Fall,” was spotted in a plush red seat at the Oscars with a bow tie around his neck. www.nytimes.com/live/2024/03...
Robert Downey Jr. won the Oscar for best supporting actor for his performance in “Oppenheimer.” The win is Downey’s first Oscar after three previous nominations. www.nytimes.com/live/2024/03...
“Poor Things” has three Oscars so far, for costume design, makeup and hairstyling, and production design. Follow more live updates from the 96th Academy Awards.

Vanessa Hudgens, one of the hosts of ABC’s Oscars pre-show, included a subtle pregnancy announcement in her coverage of the red carpet on Sunday. “I clearly have a lot to be excited for,” the actress said at the beginning of the broadcast. www.nytimes.com/2024/03/10/m...

Da’Vine Joy Randolph won the Oscar for best supporting actress for her performance in “The Holdovers.” It was Randolph’s first win at the Academy Awards on her first nomination.

Cole Brauer, 29, is on track to set a speed record for her boat class, and to be the first American woman to complete a solo, nonstop sailing race around the world.

Canada will require visas for Mexican nationals to enter the country, officials announced on Thursday. The mandate comes amid a major increase in asylum requests from Mexicans arriving in Canada.

Not many artists welcome their 70s with a new album. We spoke with Kim Gordon, the onetime Sonic Youth musician, about releasing a blistering new solo LP, finding new fans on TikTok and making art that continues to surprise. “It never occurred to me that I would be seen as cool because I’m 70.”
Breaking News: FBI agents on Thursday searched two houses owned by Winnie Greco, a close aide to New York City Mayor Eric Adams, according to two people with knowledge of the matter.

New York City Transit workers, responding to an overnight slashing attack that injured a train conductor, stopped work to file safety complaints on Thursday morning, causing severe disruptions in subway service.

Breaking News: The House passed its latest stopgap spending bill to head off a partial government shutdown, but left key issues unresolved. The Senate was expected to pass it as early as Thursday evening.

We add a leap day every four years, on Feb. 29 — today — to sync the natural world to our calendars. We spoke with a top time researcher about Julius Caesar, how leap day was invented to keep the holidays from colliding and more.
Norovirus, which can cause nausea and vomiting, is spreading in the U.S., according to the CDC. Here’s how to stay safe.
The death toll in Gaza since Israel began its military offensive against Hamas has passed more than 30,000 people, the local health ministry reported on Thursday. www.nytimes.com/2024/02/29/w...

New York City has paid more than $500 million in police misconduct settlements over the past six years, a Legal Aid Society analysis found. Fewer lawsuits are being settled each year, it reported, but the median payout has more than doubled over that time.

Breaking News: Israeli forces opened fire as a crowd gathered near aid trucks in Gaza City on Thursday in a chaotic scene in which many people were killed and injured. Palestinian and Israeli officials offered starkly different accounts of what happened.
Congressional leaders agreed to another short-term stopgap spending bill to head off a partial government shutdown at the end of the week.

Little is known about the whereabouts of Kate Middleton, the Princess of Wales, since Kensington Palace announced she had undergone “a planned abdominal surgery” in January. It's led to speculation about her health and fueled conspiracy theories online.

Breaking News: The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether Donald Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. The justices scheduled arguments for the week of April 22.
Breaking News: Richard Lewis, a comedian known for his sarcastic wit onstage, in “Curb Your Enthusiasm” and beyond, died. He was 76. nyti.ms/49SNnhG

Prince Harry lost a long-running legal battle over the downgrading of his security in Britain, as a High Court judge ruled on Wednesday that the British government was entitled to change the level of police protection for a member of the royal family who was no longer carrying out official duties.

President Biden faced a robust protest vote in Michigan over his administration’s policies toward Gaza and Israel, but his allies hope that no other state on the primary calendar will present the same challenges.

Idaho abandoned its first attempted execution in 12 years on Wednesday, after repeated tries to tap into a vein for a lethal injection on one of the nation’s longest-serving death row inmates were unsuccessful. The failure was the latest in a series of botched executions around the U.S.

Breaking News: France took a step closer to enshrining access to abortion in its Constitution as senators backed a bill calling it a “guaranteed freedom.” The politicians said the move stems from the U.S. Supreme Court's decision to overturn Roe v. Wade.
Breaking News: New York Democrats passed a new congressional map that modestly benefits them, again positioning the state as a House battleground.

Speaker Mike Johnson, who has come under bipartisan pressure to strike a deal that his far-right members are resisting, is weighing a temporary funding patch that would allow more time for negotiations and head off a partial government shutdown at the end of the week.

The Supreme Court wrestled Wednesday over whether the Trump administration acted lawfully in banning bump stocks, a firearm accessory used by the gunman during the 2017 mass shooting in Las Vegas, the deadliest in modern U.S. history. Here's what to know.

Aleksei Navalny will be buried on Friday after a funeral service in Moscow that will be open to the public, his family and aides said. They also warned that the authorities could try to prevent people from attending or force the service to be called off.

At least one in six abortions in the U.S., around 14,000 a month, were administered through telemedicine, with clinicians prescribing mail-order abortion pills after online consultations, the first nationwide count of telehealth abortions found. nyti.ms/3UXTSvb

Breaking News: Donald Trump asked a New York appeals court to accept a $100 million bond as he sought a pause to the $454 million penalty in his civil fraud case, a clear sign that the former president lacks the money to cover the full amount.

Breaking News: Hunter Biden, testifying in a private deposition, condemned House Republicans’ impeachment inquiry as a “partisan political pursuit.” He made clear in his opening statement, a copy of which was obtained by The New York Times, that he planned to cede no ground to the GOP.

Calibri has been Microsoft Word's default font for nearly two decades. Now, many users have been typing in Aptos, a sans serif typeface but with something a little extra. “We wanted it to be a little more quirky and whimsical,” Microsoft said.

A former NYU administrator admitted on Tuesday to spending $80,000 in public money meant for minority- and women-owned businesses on a swimming pool at her Connecticut home as part of a broader $3.5 million fraud she orchestrated, officials said.

Over the past decade, prevention medication known as PrEP has helped fuel a moderate drop in HIV rates. But some experts worry that the public health focus on prevention medication has accelerated a decline in condom use as the U.S. struggles to beat the HIV epidemic.

Apple has canceled its plans to release an electric car with self-driving abilities, a secretive product that had been in the works for nearly a decade. The car, which it spent billions of dollars researching, had been intended as a rival to Tesla’s EVs, which include autonomous driving features.

Wendy's plans to begin testing surge pricing as early as 2025, the fast-food chain's chief executive said during a February earnings call. In other words, the prices of menu items will rise and fall on digital menu boards based on demand.
Breaking News: Two men were found guilty in the killing of Jam Master Jay, the DJ of Run-DMC, more than 20 years after the hip-hop star’s death.

Families in Scotland were expecting to find “optical marvels” at a Willy Wonka-themed event in Glasgow. Instead, they got a short walk around a nearly empty warehouse and a visit from police officers. www.nytimes.com/2024/02/27/w...

The Alabama Supreme Court's ruling that frozen embryos in test tubes should be considered children has left IVF patients and doctors feeling legally vulnerable. The fallout raises big financial questions, too. We sought answers from experts.
Breaking News: Gov. Phil Murphy of New Jersey plans to propose restoring the nation’s highest corporate tax, which he let expire two months ago.

A day after Democrats in New York rejected a congressional map proposed by the state’s bipartisan redistricting commission, they unveiled new district lines on Tuesday designed to help their party retake the House majority this fall.

White rural rage is arguably the single greatest threat facing American democracy, our columnist Paul Krugman writes.

Drayton House has stood in Northamptonshire, England, for close to 700 years with a silent countryside presence. That peace and quiet has changed since the release of “Saltburn,” as the privately owned mansion has sparked TikTok videos and drawn tourists.

The rating for “Mary Poppins,” the children’s musical that was released 60 years ago, has been raised to PG in Britain for racist language. The British Board of Film Classification's rating change follows a wave of recontextualizing and reclassifying of films from bygone eras for modern audiences.

President Biden will convene the top four leaders of Congress at the White House on Tuesday in an attempt to break through a deadlock on Capitol Hill over keeping the government running and providing aid for Ukraine and Israel.

President Biden is expected to win Michigan’s Democratic primary election on Tuesday, but a protest campaign to persuade people to vote “uncommitted” will measure the resistance he faces within his party over his policies on Israel. Here is what to know.

The body of Laken Riley, a 22-year-old nursing student, was found in a wooded area at the University of Georgia in Athens on Thursday. The killing was believed to be the first in nearly 30 years on the campus. Here's what we know.

Macy’s said on Tuesday that it would close 150 Macy’s stores over the next three years but expand its upscale Bloomingdale’s and Bluemercury chains. It is the second major downsizing of the chain since 2020.

Hundreds of American children were poisoned last year with high doses of lead found in cinnamon-flavored applesauce pouches. Records obtained by The New York Times and The Examination show how, time and again, the contamination went unnoticed.

A cyberattack on a unit affiliated with UnitedHealthcare, the nation’s largest insurer, has disrupted drug prescription orders at thousands of pharmacies for nearly a week.

An internal review by the Pentagon of Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin’s failure to tell President Biden and other senior leaders that he was in the hospital faults no one with the breach of protocol.

The co-chair of a task force set up by Harvard University to combat antisemitism has resigned. It was the latest blow to the university’s efforts to address complaints that Jewish students have felt increasingly uncomfortable on campus since Oct. 7.

Russia’s invasion came in two phases, many Ukrainians say: the first a decade ago, when it sent soldiers over the border in an unacknowledged military intervention, and the second when it began its full assault two years ago.

German lawmakers approved legalization of marijuana on Friday. The measure still requires approval from the Council of States, but the vote brings Germany a step closer to becoming the largest nation in Europe to legalize the drug for recreational use.
Michigan will hold its primary on Feb. 27, with voting for Republicans and Democrats. Additionally, the state’s Republican Party will host a nominating convention on March 2. Here’s what to know.

A monkey is on the loose after escaping a zoo in the Scottish Highlands. Park officials are using thermal drones to help them search for the animal and have asked locals to report sightings.

An Iranian man accused of being the kingpin of a network that targets dissidents has been charged with hiring two Canadians, including a member of the Hells Angels, to kill two Iranian refugees living in Maryland, according to indictments unsealed Monday.

Professors at the University of Pennsylvania staged a rally last week in protest of a recent proposal drafted by Marc Rowan, the billionaire and major donor who led a campaign to oust the school’s president, Elizabeth Magill.
Charles Littlejohn, a former IRS contractor accused of leaking the tax documents of Donald Trump and other wealthy Americans, was sentenced on Monday to five years in prison.

Air defenses failed to stop a deadly attack on a U.S. military outpost in Jordan on Sunday because the drone homed in on its target at the same time a U.S. drone was returning to the base, officials said Monday. Three U.S. service members were killed. nyti.ms/3u31Ubr
Pandora, the world’s largest jewelry company by units sold, has started to source only 100%-recycled silver and gold for its collections. Is that as good as it sounds? Here’s what experts say.

Donald Trump’s lawyers want Fani Willis, the main prosecutor in the Georgia election interference case, to be disqualified over accusations that she had a romantic relationship with a subordinate. A judge will decide what happens next. Here’s what to know.
There's a bewildering set of dates and formats in this year's U.S. presidential primary season. That has voting experts worried.

“Why did I suffer for 30 years to share intimate things of my family, of my pain, of my desperation?” Liliana Segre, 93, an Italian Holocaust survivor, says the rise in anti-Semitism has made her wonder these days if “I’ve lived in vain.”

A UN team has arrived in Israel to examine reports of sexual violence during the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7. The visit comes after multiple news organizations, including The New York Times, reported allegations of rape and mutilation in the attack.

About 1,300 hate crimes were reported in elementary schools, secondary schools and colleges in the U.S. in 2022, up from 700 in 2018. Black students were the most frequent reported victims, followed by LGBTQ and Jewish students, according to FBI data. nyti.ms/48a4mLf

Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin returned to the Pentagon on Monday, after his surgery for prostate cancer and hospitalization for related medical complications. He was criticized for failing to immediately disclose his illness and absence to the White House.

China Evergrande, a massive property company with developments that cover hundreds of cities, has been ordered to dismantle itself. The developer epitomized China’s real estate frenzy, and its 2021 fall fueled the market’s downturn. Here's what to know:
Breaking News: A U.S. drone was returning to a base in Jordan as another attacked on Sunday, confusing defenses before a strike killed 3 U.S. soldiers, officials said.

The man who stole a pair of Dorothy’s ruby slippers used in “The Wizard of Oz” from the Judy Garland Museum nearly 20 years ago said he believed the slippers were adorned with real rubies. He was sentenced to time served and a year of probation.
The time American viewers spent streaming TV shows and movies went up last year. What did they watch? A lot of reruns, it turns out.
Taylor Swift is not shown nearly as much during Kansas City games as some football fans might think. Here’s data to prove it.

Disposable vapes will be banned in Britain, Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said, after surveys suggest an uptick in the number of young people vaping. He also unveiled measures to ban single-use vapes, restrict flavors, and regulate packaging and displays.

Daily or near-daily use of substances by teens was linked to a moderate increase in psychiatric symptoms, new research has found. Researchers described the connection as “dose dependent,” because the level of use was linked to the intensity of symptoms.
Breaking News: South Africa’s African National Congress suspended former President Jacob Zuma, punishing him for endorsing a rival party.
More than previous generations, today’s teens are concerned about their mental health, disillusioned by politicians and pessimistic about their futures, new surveys show. nyti.ms/3vVdB4o

Joni Mitchell, who has won nine competitive Grammys, is set to perform at the Grammy Awards for the first time on Sunday. Organizers offered no details about the performance, including whether she is expected to play solo.

Nikki Haley is trying to find a way to diminish Donald Trump’s hold on the Republican party’s electorate without decisively turning conservative voters against her the way they have destroyed other Trump critics.

After a freight train carrying hazardous chemicals derailed in East Palestine, Ohio a year ago, the rail industry pledged to work to become safer, and members of Congress vowed to prevent similar disasters. No bill was passed and accidents went up.

With Ukraine once again in need of new troops to fend off Russia, military leaders can no longer rely solely on enthusiasm. More men are avoiding military service, while calls to demobilize exhausted frontline soldiers have grown.

Soldiers who seized power in three West African nations announced on Sunday that they would pull their countries out of their regional economic bloc because of sanctions the group imposed in response to the coups.

Authorities have identified the last known person to have died in the wildfire that tore through Lahaina on the island of Maui in Hawaii on Aug. 8.

Young and old, the 100 lives lost won’t be forgotten.
News Analysis: In two civil trials, Donald Trump has showcased his disdain for the legal system and provided a preview of how he might handle himself when any of his four criminal cases go to trial.
Breaking News: Three U.S. soldiers were killed and 25 others were injured in a drone strike by an Iran-backed militia in Jordan.

House Republicans released two articles of impeachment against Alejandro Mayorkas, the homeland security secretary, accusing him of refusing to uphold the law and breaching the public trust in his handling of immigration. www.nytimes.com/2024/01/28/u...

As soon as E. Jean Carroll heard the verdict — $83.3 million in defamation damages against Donald Trump — a world of possibility opened before her. “I’m not going to waste a cent of this,” she said. “We’re going to do something good with it.” nyti.ms/3UhHaY7
Israeli military and intelligence officials have concluded that a significant number of weapons used by Hamas in the Oct. 7 attacks and in the war in Gaza came from the Israeli military itself.

A network of Republican megadonors has invited aides to both Donald Trump and Nikki Haley to make presentations at the group’s winter meeting next week, as the wealthy contributors assess the presidential race with just nine months until Election Day.

The artist Gillian Laub has created a new photo archive of more than 200 Holocaust survivors.

On Saturday, some of those portraits were projected onto buildings and structures throughout New York City.

Two protesters from an environmental group threw pumpkin-colored soup on the Mona Lisa at the Louvre museum in Paris on Sunday. The artwork is behind bulletproof glass and did not appear to sustain damage.

Roberta Kaplan, the writer E. Jean Carroll's lawyer, and Donald Trump hurled accusations at each other.

On Friday, Kaplan emerged as the victor when a jury decided that Trump should pay her client $83.3 million for defamation.
The number of high-profile political races taking shape in New Jersey — combined with an array of atypical candidates — have set an early, take-your-breath-away pace this year.
Top American, Israeli and Arab officials are trying to forge a set of deals to end the war in Gaza and answer the divisive question of how the territory will be governed after the fighting stops.

President Biden will campaign in South Carolina this weekend, ahead of the Democrats’ first official primary next Saturday. Nikki Haley is preparing for a daunting battle against Trump in the state’s Republican primary.

Follow the latest election news.

At least four donor nations are joining the U.S. in temporarily halting funding to the UN agency aiding Palestinians in Gaza, after it fired a dozen of its employees accused by Israel of participating in the Oct. 7 attacks.

Follow updates.

23andMe is being accused in a class-action lawsuit of failing to protect the privacy of customers whose personal information was exposed last year in a data breach that affected nearly seven million profiles.

A Manhattan jury on Friday ordered Donald Trump to pay $83.3 million to the writer E. Jean Carroll for defaming her ever since she first accused him of rape. Trump was found liable last year of sexually abusing her in the mid-1990s. nyti.ms/3vSLm6t

The lake that allows the Panama Canal to function recorded the lowest water level ever for the start of a dry season this year, meaning fewer ships can pass through. Climate change has made rainfall patterns much less predictable.
Pets can develop hypothermia and frostbite. They can also slip on ice, or face cold-related paw injuries. Here’s how to keep them safe when temperatures plummet. nyti.ms/3vRZL2I
Some football fans saw Jason Kelce. LJ Rader, the man behind the social media accounts Art But Make It Sports, saw “The Feast of Bacchus.” nyti.ms/3Sho1D3
Breaking News: The UN agency that aids Palestinians, known as UNRWA, fired several workers and is investigating allegations of their involvement in the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks.

The first American execution in which death was caused by suffocation with nitrogen gas took place in Alabama on Thursday. It gave no indication of settling the legal, moral and technical questions around capital punishment that have long worried states.
Malia Obama showcased her short film "The Heart" — an 18-minute-long project that focuses on a sensitive man racked with guilt when his mother dies after they argue — at the Sundance Film Festival.

Many economists spent early 2023 predicting a painful downturn, but the widely predicted recession never showed up. Now, experts are assessing what the unexpected resilience tells us about the future.

After Elon Musk bought Twitter, now X, he dismantled its system to flag false election content.

Musk, who has spread misinformation himself on X, said the system amounted to election interference, raising alarms among experts and election administrators.

U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen defended the Biden administration’s economic agenda on Thursday, as President Biden begins to make the general election argument that he has been a stronger steward of the economy than Donald Trump.
Donald Trump’s victories in Iowa and New Hampshire were the product of a win-or-else ethos, a fractured opposition and his power to make the Republican party stand for whatever he stands for.

The International Court of Justice is set to issue a decision Friday on South Africa’s demand that Israel immediately suspend its military offensive in Gaza, although the court has few means of enforcement.

Here’s what you should know about the ruling.

Donald Trump will take the witness stand and testify in his own defense Thursday in the trial of E. Jean Carroll’s defamation lawsuit against him, the former president’s lawyer said.

Follow live.

The main super PAC backing Nikki Haley said Thursday that it had raised $50.1 million in the second half of 2023.

It's a hefty sum that eclipses the more than $46 million that the leading super PAC backing Donald Trump said it had raised in the same time.

After learning how AI is trained on other people’s artwork, some users asked it to make popular images. It made a nearly identical copyrighted photo. Tests like these raise questions about the AI's data and whether companies are violating copyright laws.

The FTC launched an inquiry into deals Microsoft, Amazon and Google made with start-ups, part of an effort to rein in Big Tech on AI. These deals have allowed the companies to form deep ties with their smaller rivals while dodging most government scrutiny.

Breaking News: Peter Navarro, a trade adviser to former President Donald Trump, was sentenced to four months in prison for defying a subpoena from the House committee investigating the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.

Letter volumes in Britain have halved since 2011, with more people sending emails and texts over handwritten notes.

But a proposal to reduce the Royal Mail's delivery to just three days a week from six is meeting resistance from lawmakers and businesses.

These are the U.S. cities where Gen Z-ers — specifically older members who are early in their careers — have the best and worst chances of buying a home based on earnings and employment data, a recent study found. nyti.ms/4b4XtNX
A Russian court on Thursday sentenced a woman to 27 years in prison for delivering a bomb in a statuette that killed influential military blogger Maksim Fomin in a St. Petersburg cafe last year.

Microsoft said Thursday that it would eliminate 1,900 roles in its video game division, including at Xbox and Activision Blizzard, the maker of games like Call of Duty and Guitar Hero. The nearly 9% reduction comes three months after the tech giant completed its $69 billion acquisition of Blizzard.

The housing market has been bogged down by high prices, soaring mortgage rates and a lack of inventory in the past year. This has spurred a rise in construction, as developers rushed to meet demand and dangled incentives to entice buyers.

Maximila Imali, a top Kenyan sprinter, did not break any rules to lose her eligibility for the Paris Olympics. Instead, she is set to miss the games because she was born with a rare genetic variant that results in naturally elevated levels of testosterone. nyti.ms/3HyQaAA
What Donald Trump meant as a barb at Nikki Haley about her dress may have ultimately highlighted the look, and the message, she was going for in New Hampshire, our chief fashion critic writes.

A jury in Portland, Oregon, awarded $85 million to nine people who had losses from wildfires that burned millions of acres in 2020. It's the latest development against PacifiCorp, which was found liable for damages for not cutting power despite warnings.

Fifteen months after San Francisco officials were ready to throw a party to celebrate $1.7 million in funding for a tiny public bathroom, nothing but mulch remains in its place. The project has come to symbolize the city’s bureaucratic inefficiencies. www.nytimes.com/2024/01/24/u...

Mayor Eric Adams on Wednesday used his third State of the City address to deliver an upbeat overview of his tenure, highlighting improvements in public safety and jobs while playing down the migrant crisis that has overwhelmed New York City’s shelter system.

Ohio lawmakers on Wednesday overrode Gov. Mike DeWine’s veto of a bill that would bar transgender minors from receiving gender-affirming care. The move by the Republican-controlled state legislature cleared the way for the law to go into effect in 90 days.

The Houthis — an Iran-backed militia that controls northwestern Yemen — have long been skilled producers of propaganda, crafting television shows and music videos. But they've never had as large an audience as they do now.

News Analysis: New Hampshire has a way of offering politicians second chances and the occasional upset. But Nikki Haley, with a tightly controlled campaign that limited her exposure, played it safe and never gave voters a reason to throw her a life vest.

Bloomberg Businessweek's next editor will be Brad Stone, the company said on Wednesday. Stone, a veteran technology journalist, was most recently the senior executive editor of Bloomberg News's global technology team, which he has led since 2015.

A performance artist has sued the Museum of Modern Art, saying that officials neglected to take corrective action after several visitors groped him during a nude performance for the 2010 retrospective “Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present.”

NPR has announced that Katherine Maher will be its next chief executive. Maher, who will take over at NPR during a critical period, was previously the chief executive of the Wikimedia Foundation, a nonprofit that supports Wikipedia.

In Cindy Sherman’s electrifying new work, eyes spin out in different directions. Noses and mouths engage in pitched conflict. “You’re seeing the face and imagining that it’s moved through space,” the artist said. Take a look.

New Jersey Transit, facing a budget deficit, said on Wednesday that it plans to raise fares by 15% in July and an additional 3% annually after that. The fare increases would be the agency’s first since Gov. Philip Murphy took office six years ago.

How do you make the best cup of tea? Add a pinch of salt, according to an American chemistry professor.

Not everyone in Britain is eager to embrace the idea.
Breaking News: The White House will delay approval of the largest natural gas export terminal to mull its climate impacts, people familiar with the plan said.

Jon Stewart will return to host “The Daily Show” on Monday nights during the 2024 election campaign, the network said on Wednesday. The announcement comes after the comedian parted ways with his Apple show, “The Problem With Jon Stewart,” in 2023. nyti.ms/3SwNIR2

Argentina’s largest labor unions — workers in transportation, construction, health care and other jobs — are planning a nationwide strike on Wednesday to protest President Javier Milei’s planned overhauls, arguing they would weaken workers' protections.
Boeing’s stock has fallen nearly 15% since a panel flew off a 737 Max 9 jet during an Alaska Airlines flight shortly after takeoff on Jan. 5.

Breaking News: Jon Stewart will return to host “The Daily Show” on Monday nights during the 2024 election campaign. Stewart, who hosted the Comedy Central show from 1999 to 2015, will also be an executive producer.

A record number of voters cast a ballot in New Hampshire’s Republican primary on Tuesday, according to a New York Times analysis of election data, with a total of more than 300,000 votes as of early Wednesday.

Donald Trump did better than Nikki Haley in 154 of the 214 New Hampshire townships that have reported votes. Like in Iowa, his greatest support came from areas with lower shares of college-educated voters. www.nytimes.com/interactive/...
President Biden will appear with the president of the United Automobile Workers union at a conference in Washington on Wednesday as he tries to secure the group’s influential endorsement.

New Hampshire voters streamed into polling sites on Tuesday in the first presidential primary of 2024. Donald Trump expressed confidence he would win, while Nikki Haley, seeking an upset, vowed to stay in the race even if she lost. Follow live updates.

A 33-year-old man has been arrested twice in roughly 48 hours after stalking Taylor Swift outside her Manhattan home, the police said on Tuesday. He was charged with two counts of harassment and two counts of stalking.

After Gov. Ron DeSantis dropped out of the Republican presidential race this week, his supporters in Florida can't wait for him to renew his focus on the state. But critics are dreading what his final three years on the job might bring.

The journalist Motaz Azaiza has left Gaza. He, and other Palestinians who've been covering the Israeli bombardment, spoke with us about living and covering the harrowing experiences, such as the deaths of colleagues, and then sharing the aftermath online.

After years of QR codes, physical menus are back with more personality than ever.

We visited hundreds of restaurants of varying styles, cuisines and price points — and left with 121 menus. They provide a snapshot of the distinctive new shape of dining.

“Poor Things,” “Killers of the Flower Moon” and “Barbie” all scored multiple nods in a strong year for movies, with “Oppenheimer” nominated for 13 Academy Awards, including best picture. Follow our live Oscars coverage here.

New York City has agreed to change the way it selects tenants for affordable housing in order to settle a long-running civil rights case that asserted the city’s housing system reinforced segregation.

A Harvard task force on antisemitism has gotten off to a rocky start, with complaints that the professor of Jewish history who was chosen to help lead the panel had signed a letter that was critical of Israel.

Vice President Kamala Harris will travel to Wisconsin on Monday, the 51st anniversary of Roe v. Wade, to announce new steps the Biden administration has taken to support abortion access since the Supreme Court overturned the ruling in 2022.

Monday will be the last full day of campaigning before New Hampshire voters head to the polls in what is now a race for the Republican presidential nomination between Donald Trump and Nikki Haley.

Follow updates.

President Biden is cruising to the Democratic nomination and Donald Trump could begin to wrap up his party’s nod within days. As both men head toward a fall rematch, an undercurrent of disbelief is coursing through the country.

A group of Silicon Valley billionaires is trying to build a city from the ground up in Solano County, an agricultural region in California. But some of the locals whose families have been there for generations don’t want to sell the land.
Breaking News: Mayor Eric Adams of New York vetoed a bill banning solitary confinement in the city’s jails and a bill requiring the police to document more interactions with the public.

Breaking News: A French court convicted three police officers in one of the country’s highest-profile police abuse cases. The case centered on a young Black man who sustained serious injuries during a violent 2017 arrest.

The group that publishes Sports Illustrated said in an email on Friday that it was laying off many, if not all, of the employees who work at the magazine, leaving the future of the publication in doubt.

Breaking News: Alec Baldwin will once again face an involuntary manslaughter charge in the death of a cinematographer in New Mexico on the film “Rust,” months after the original case against him was dismissed.
Six to 12 million children age 3 to 11 get lice every year, according to estimates from the CDC. Here’s how to identify and deal with an infestation. nyti.ms/4b74wFR
An expanded child tax credit. A boost for affordable housing. Tax breaks for companies. Here’s a look at what’s in the new bipartisan tax deal.

A Japanese robotic spacecraft successfully set down on the moon on Friday. 

With this achievement, Japan is now the fifth country to send a spacecraft that made a soft landing on the moon.
Breaking News: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, a former presidential candidate, plans to endorse Donald Trump today at a rally, two people briefed on the matter said.

Anti-abortion demonstrators celebrated the overturning of Roe v. Wade last year. Now the thousands of people who are expected at the annual March for Life on Friday represent a movement that is splintered over strategy and immediate goals.

After a humbling loss in Iowa, Gov. Ron DeSantis is starting to signal that he is building an off-ramp from the race for the Republican presidential nomination, a seeming acknowledgment of his dim prospects of defeating Donald Trump.

Apple’s low-key approach to the Vision Pro, its new augmented reality device priced at $3,500, speaks to the challenges associated with selling a product that could still be years away from appealing to mainstream consumers.
See a map of the 5.6-magnitude earthquake that struck Colombia on Friday morning. As seismologists review available data, they may revise the earthquake’s reported magnitude.

The Justice Department published an examination of the law enforcement response to the Uvalde school massacre in 2022, finding “cascading failures of leadership, decision-making, tactics, policy and training.” Here are the takeaways from the report.
Fani Willis, the district attorney prosecuting the Georgia election interference case against Donald Trump, is fighting a subpoena for her to testify in a colleague’s divorce proceedings.

Breaking News: The House passed a stopgap spending bill hours after the Senate voted on the measure, moving to fund federal agencies through March. President Biden expected to sign it before the midnight deadline on Friday.

Grindavik, a fishing town in southwestern Iceland, is still under the threat of volcanic eruptions, and experts consider it uninhabitable in the near future. The authorities are scrambling to house 3,700 residents and contain their financial losses.

Billionaires have swooped in to buy some of the most fabled news brands in the last decade. Time magazine, The Washington Post and The Los Angeles Times — owned by Marc Benioff, Jeff Bezos, and Dr. Patrick Soon-Shiong — are still losing money.

Hundreds of protesters in Russia clashed with the police on Wednesday after a local court sentenced an advocate for the local Bashkir ethnic minority to four years in prison. He was convicted of inciting ethnic discord and discrediting the Russian army.

Hundreds of coffee farmers in Hawaii's Kona region recently won a series of settlements — totaling more than $41 million — after a nearly five-year legal battle with distributors and retailers that were accused of using the Kona name in a misleading way.
Will airline prices finally drop? Will AI change your vacation? Here's what travelers should expect to face in 2024.
A man was arrested in Brazil on Thursday in connection with the killing of Brent Sikkema, a New York art dealer who was found with stab wounds in his Rio de Janeiro apartment this week.

While writing her best seller, “Come as You Are,” the sex educator Emily Nagoski and her husband stopped having sex. The self-proclaimed “sex nerd” dug into the science of maintaining intimacy in long-term relationships. It's now the subject of her new book. www.nytimes.com/2024/01/18/w...
California now has a state bat. The pallid bat, or Antrozous pallidus, joins a long list of official Golden State symbols, including a new state mushroom. www.nytimes.com/2024/01/18/u...

Abortion-rights groups in Missouri kicked off a campaign on Thursday to establish a right to the procedure in the state constitution. It sets up the next big test of public support for legalized abortion in a state that has enacted one of the strictest bans in the country.

The Senate was expected to pass legislation on Thursday to fund the government through early March, putting pressure on the House to quickly follow suit to avoid a partial government shutdown beginning Saturday.

Breaking News: “Cascading failures” in policing hindered the response to the deadly 2022 school shooting in Uvalde, Texas, in which 21 people were killed at Robb Elementary School, the Justice Department found.

Elma, a 14,000-year-old female woolly mammoth, was born in what is now the Yukon then traveled to Alaska where she stayed until she reached about 20. She's one of the ancient stories scientists are finding through the minerals on tusks of mammoths.

A Maine judge ordered the secretary of state on Wednesday to wait for a U.S. Supreme Court ruling before putting into effect her decision to exclude Donald Trump from the state’s Republican primary ballot.

China said 9.02 million babies were born in 2023, the seventh year in a row that its birth rate has fallen. The shrinking and aging population worries officials because it is draining the country of the working-age people it needs to power the economy. nyti.ms/3S1hkok

Three Tacoma police officers who were acquitted in the death of Manuel Ellis, a Black man who died in police custody in 2020 after pleading that he could not breathe, will each receive $500,000 for resigning, according to documents released on Tuesday.

Why are drug prices so high in the U.S.?

Research shows pharmaceutical prices are nearly double in some well-off countries. Here are six reasons drugs are so costly.
Breaking News: Speaker Mike Johnson signaled before a meeting with President Biden that a compromise on immigration that allows aid to Ukraine was not possible.

One of Norway’s top policy bodies recommended a halt to all foreign adoptions amid a probe into allegations of stolen children, forged paperwork and illegal, adoption-for-profit schemes. The sweeping adoptions scheme first came to light in 2021.

King Charles III will undergo treatment for an enlarged prostate next week, Buckingham Palace said, describing it as a “corrective procedure” for a benign condition. The announcement came after the news Catherine, Princess of Wales, had abdominal surgery.

Frozen gas infrastructure in Texas was the main culprit in the power failures of 2021, which was blamed for some 240 deaths. After help from wind power, the grid appears to be holding this week as wind chills dipped below 0 degrees Fahrenheit.
Watching “Oppenheimer,” our congressional correspondent wondered (perhaps a bit obsessively): How did the president get the $2 billion secret project past Congress?

A group of passengers who signed up for the failed three-year Life at Sea cruise are pursuing legal action against the Turkish company after more than a month of missed refunds, claiming it collected millions of dollars toward a deposit.

A fireworks factory exploded in central Thailand on Wednesday, killing at least 20 people and injuring many others, according to the Thai police. It was unclear what caused the explosion, which was the second such accident in the country since 2022.

CNN canceled the Republican debate it was set to host before the New Hampshire primary because only Ron DeSantis agreed to participate, the network said on Wednesday, a day after ABC News did the same.

Cancer deaths in the U.S. are falling — with four million deaths prevented since 1991 — according to the American Cancer Society’s annual report, which highlighted declines in smoking, early detection and greatly improved treatments.
Breaking News: Catherine, the Princess of Wales, underwent abdominal surgery and will remain hospitalized for up to 14 days, officials said.

Michael Bloomberg and other billionaires have contributed to a legal defense fund for Mayor Eric Adams amid a federal corruption investigation into his campaign fund-raising. The fund raised $732,000 in less than two months, according to a filing submitted Tuesday.
Mayor Eric Adams on Tuesday proposed a $109 billion budget and said that New York City’s financial outlook had improved. He still called for more federal funding to help pay for the migrant crisis.

The Emmys on Monday reunited the casts of several beloved series, which included “The Sopranos,” “Martin,” “Grey’s Anatomy” and “Cheers.”
