Skyhorse Publishing, which has built a reputation for taking on books other houses consider too controversial to publish, has signed a deal to buy Regnery Publishing, a conservative press that has published Donald Trump, Senator Rand Paul and Ann Coulter.
During the first six weeks of the war in Gaza, Israel routinely dropped 2,000-pound bombs in areas it designated safe for civilians, according to an analysis of visual evidence by The New York Times.

Landon Bryant has amassed hundreds of thousands of followers on social media this year. He talks about grits, prayer lists and humidity, addressing a diverse audience bound by its fascination with a colorful, complicated place: the South.
Breaking News: A U.S. strike killed a leader of a Somali terrorist group accused of planning attacks that killed 148 Kenyans and three Americans, officials say.

A jury found three Tacoma police officers not guilty on Thursday of all criminal charges in the death of Manuel “Manny” Ellis, a Black man who died in police custody in 2020. He had pleaded that he could not breathe after police punched and restrained him.

The company that operates Pornhub and other adult websites acknowledged in federal court in Brooklyn on Thursday that it had profited for years from pornographic content that depicted sex trafficking victims, according to federal prosecutors.
Breaking News: The U.S. said it was ready to back a UN resolution calling for more desperately needed aid to the Gaza Strip, after a week of delays and negotiations. The timing of a vote was unclear.
A federal appeals court ruled against the band Nirvana on Thursday, reviving a lawsuit about the group’s use of a naked baby on the cover of its 1991 album “Nevermind.”
Whole Foods did not violate the law when it punished employees in 2020 for wearing apparel supporting the Black Lives Matter movement, a federal administrative judge ruled on Wednesday.

A New Hampshire man who was charged with threatening to kill Vivek Ramaswamy has been indicted by a federal grand jury with additional counts for threatening the lives of Chris Christie and another unnamed presidential candidate, according to an indictment filed on Wednesday.

When Kevin McCallister gets chased out of The Plaza in “Home Alone 2,” he heads to the Upper West Side, where his Uncle Rob has a brownstone, to take on the Wet Bandits. It wasn't actually in the 1992 film, but it is now on the market for $6.7 million.
Rite Aid used facial recognition technology to falsely and disproportionately identify people of color and women as likely shoplifters, the Federal Trade Commission said on Tuesday.

Close to 20,000 Palestinians have been killed during the 10 weeks of Israel's war in the territory, Gaza officials said. The death toll has surpassed that of any other Arab conflict with Israel in more than 40 years. Experts say it is likely an undercount.

Trade between Russia and China surpassed $200 billion in the first 11 months of this year, a level the countries had not expected to reach until 2024. The biggest winners from the surge in trade have been their vehicle manufacturers.

Israel’s military said it learned that a combat dog equipped with a camera, captured the voices of the three hostages before they were mistakenly killed by Israeli troops in Gaza last week. The footage was unchecked at the time, officials said.
Breaking News: Rudy Giuliani filed for bankruptcy, a day after he was ordered to pay $148 million in damages to two former Georgia election workers.

Eurostar, the high-speed passenger train that runs under the English Channel, halted service between Paris and London on Thursday because of “an unexpected strike” at the Channel Tunnel, leading to travel chaos ahead of Christmas.
Update: Ten people were killed and nine seriously wounded in a shooting at a university in central Prague, authorities said. The shooter also died.
Senator John Fetterman of Pennsylvania, who has angered liberal Democrats with his stance on Israel and on immigration, assailed the left and said he no longer considers himself a progressive.
Breaking News: Several people were killed in a shooting at Charles University in central Prague, Czech police said.

Justice Clarence Thomas pressed congressional lawmakers for a higher salary early in his tenure on the Supreme Court, threatening to resign and inspiring a campaign by Republican backers to meet his demands, according to a memo addressed to the chief justice in June 2000.

Nearly 30 years after a bombing at a Jewish community center in Buenos Aires killed 85 people, federal prosecutors in Manhattan accused a man in Lebanon of helping plan the attack and leading decades of terrorism for Hezbollah.
Two teenagers were found guilty on Wednesday of murdering Brianna Ghey, a 16-year-old transgender girl who was stabbed 28 times at a park in northwest England in February.

Rudy Giuliani must immediately pay the $148 million he owes to two former Georgia election workers he was found to have defamed, a federal judge ordered on Wednesday, citing concerns that he might “conceal his assets” if he were allowed to wait.
A man involved in a brazen plot to manipulate the stock price of a New Jersey deli’s parent company pleaded guilty to securities fraud on Wednesday.

The city of Boston issued a formal apology on Wednesday to Alan Swanson and Willie Bennett, two Black men who were falsely linked to the 1989 murder of Carol Stuart in a high-profile case that spotlighted Boston’s history of racism.

An Oklahoma man who was convicted of murder in 1975 was exonerated in court on Tuesday after spending more than 48 years in prison, the authorities said. He served the longest wrongful sentence in the U.S., according to a registry of cases.
Warner Bros. Discovery has expressed interest in a possible merger with Paramount, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.
The New York City Council passed a bill on Wednesday that would limit the ability of landlords to use criminal records to screen tenants.
Breaking News: The New York City Council banned most uses of solitary confinement in city jails, defying Mayor Eric Adams, who may veto the measure.

After 5-year-old twins on Monday were found by their mother dead and foaming at the mouth in their Bronx apartment, the authorities, who said they have no evidence to suggest foul play, still do not know how they died.
Two Covid variants, HV.1 and JN.1, now comprise roughly half of all cases in the U.S. Here's what to know.

President Biden said on Wednesday that it was “self-evident” that Donald Trump had supported an insurrection on Jan. 6, 2021, but that the courts would decide whether he should be on the ballot in 2024.

Donald Trump is ineligible to hold office again under the 14th Amendment, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled this week. At least 16 other states currently have pending legal challenges to his eligibility for office. Here's where they stand.

Donald Trump urged the Supreme Court on Wednesday to put off a decision on a crucial question in his federal prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election: whether he has “absolute immunity” for actions he took as president.

Southwest Airlines and its pilots union reached a tentative deal on a five-year labor contract that would raise wages and increase retirement benefits. The union’s board approved the deal, which it said was worth $12 billion, Wednesday, sending it to a vote of the more than 11,000 union members.
Breaking News: The U.S. agreed to release a close ally of President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela in exchange for 10 jailed Americans, White House officials said.

Donald Trump continues to march to the 2024 Republican presidential nomination with a commanding lead over his primary rivals, even as a majority of U.S. voters believe he has committed serious federal crimes, a New York Times and Siena College poll found. nyti.ms/3RybCtL

Trump "has perfected a playbook of victimhood, raising campaign funds off each indictment and encouraging Republican officials to defend him," Maggie Haberman writes. "He and his allies are already folding the Colorado ruling into that same narrative."

“Buy Now, Pay Later” loans, which allow consumers to pay for purchases in installments, are helping to fuel a record-setting holiday shopping season. But economists worry they could also be masking and exacerbating cracks in Americans’ financial well-being.

China is quietly rebuilding a military base equipped to test a new generation of nuclear weapons, new evidence shows. The move, experts say, could increase the lethality of its rapidly growing arsenal and result in a new age of atomic rivalry.

New York City Council is expected on Wednesday to pass a bill that would ban solitary confinement in most cases. Opponents of the practice call the bill long overdue for the jail system, most notably at Rikers Island, which is at risk of a federal takeover.
The Senate confirmed nearly a dozen military officers to four-star positions on Tuesday, ending Senator Tommy Tuberville’s nearly yearlong blockade of promotions for senior generals and admirals.

A former leader of the Proud Boys who helped the government investigate and prosecute others in the far-right group involved in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, was sentenced on Tuesday to 40 months in prison for his own role in the assault.

California approved new regulations on Tuesday to allow wastewater from showers and toilets to be purified into drinking water, as the nation’s most populous state braces for years of drought-induced shortages.

A former New York City police officer was sentenced on Tuesday to 22 months in prison for her role in the Capitol riot on Jan. 6, 2021, during which, federal prosecutors said, she pushed against and slapped police officers while yelling and wielding a tambourine.

President Volodymyr Zelensky pushed back against doubts about Ukraine’s battlefield prospects and about the support of its allies, telling reporters on Tuesday that his country is not losing the war and is prepared to negotiate with Russia, but only on its own terms.

Donald Trump is ineligible to hold office again because he engaged in insurrection with his actions leading up to the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol, Colorado’s top court ruled on Tuesday. Follow live updates: www.nytimes.com/live/2023/12...

A federal appeals court on Tuesday issued a temporary order limiting the Biden administration’s authority to remove barbed wire erected by Texas along the U.S.-Mexico border as part of the state’s effort to deter migrants from crossing into the United States.

Donald Trump is ineligible to hold office again, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled, disqualifying him from the state’s primary ballot. The decision is likely to put the basic contours of the 2024 presidential election in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/19/u...
Breaking News: Donald Trump is ineligible to hold office again, the Colorado Supreme Court ruled, disqualifying him from the state’s primary ballot.
Breaking News: France’s Parliament passed an immigration overhaul after President Emmanuel Macron compromised with the right, a move that set off a crisis in his party.

Games Workshop, the company behind Warhammer 40,000, announced on Monday that it had reached a deal with Amazon Studios to bring the tabletop game to life on TV and film screens. The actor Henry Cavill will appear on the show and be its executive producer.

NASA streamed high-definition video — this one of a cat named Taters chasing a laser pointer — 18.6 million miles away, the farthest ever. The demonstration marked another step toward improving the infrastructure for communication beyond the Earth’s orbit.

The panel's creation comes after a New York Times investigation this month that revealed how a nationwide shortage of air traffic controllers has resulted in an exhausted and demoralized work force that is increasingly prone to making dangerous mistakes.

The Federal Aviation Administration is planning to form a panel to look into the potential risks posed by exhaustion among air traffic controllers, many of whom have been working round-the-clock schedules, after a spate of close calls this year.

After days of negotiations with the U.S., the UN Security Council is expected to vote Tuesday on a resolution calling for a pause in fighting between Israel and Hamas long enough to deliver aid to Gaza, and for the immediate release of hostages there.

The Houthis, an armed group backed by Iran, have been attacking ships in the Red Sea since Hamas attacked Israel on Oct. 7, forcing some shipping companies to avoid the Suez Canal. It could hamper global trade and push up the cost of imported goods.
Breaking News: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York signed a bill that will create the second statewide task force in the U.S. to examine reparations for descendants of slavery. nyti.ms/4aqmC5b

Voters broadly disapprove of the way President Biden is handling the war in Gaza, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found, with younger Americans far more critical than older voters of both Israel’s conduct and of the administration’s response. nyti.ms/4as6Zu0
Neil the seal has shown up on doorsteps and slept on the road. But residents in Tasmania, Australia, have been forgiving to the more than 1,300-pound southern elephant seal.

Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, the first woman on the Supreme Court who died this month at 93, is being honored at the National Cathedral. President Biden and Chief Justice John Roberts will speak.

Watch the funeral service live:

The premise of Reading Rhythms is simple: Show up with a book, commit to vanquishing a chapter or two and chat with strangers about what you’ve just read. 

Since May the "reading parties" have been in New York, Los Angeles and Croatia.
A veteran political operative who played a mysterious role in the George Santos scandal now appears to be spearheading a newly formed super PAC that is supporting Ron DeSantis in Iowa.
The super PAC aligned with Donald Trump is putting money for the first time behind television ads attacking Nikki Haley, his former UN ambassador, who has gained momentum in the Republican primary.

Two former Georgia election workers who successfully sued Rudy Giuliani for spreading baseless lies about them sued him again on Monday, seeking to bar him from continuing to make unfounded accusations that they cheated Donald Trump out of votes in the 2020 election.

A jury in Washington State decided on Monday that Monsanto should pay $857 million to former students and parent volunteers who said they had been exposed at a school to dangerous chemicals made by the company and later became sick, according to court records.
Breaking News: A 5.9-magnitude earthquake in northwestern China has killed at least 111 people and injured more than 200, Chinese state media reported.
Breaking News: A volcano in Iceland began erupting, with lava fountains reaching up to 330 feet and the glow visible from central Reykjavik.

A campaign watchdog group filed a complaint on Monday with the Federal Election Commission against Ron DeSantis's campaign and a super PAC backing his presidential bid, accusing them of a "textbook example" of illegal campaign coordination.

A quarter of the U.S.'s roughly 30,000 United Methodist churches — which once dominated the country's religious landscape — have left the denomination, according to the church's news agency. At issue is the question of ordaining and marrying LGBTQ people.
Breaking News: Texas will allow state and local authorities to arrest migrants entering from Mexico, setting up a fight with the federal government over immigration.

A computer showed chimpanzees and bonobos pairs of ape faces for three seconds at a time: one of a stranger and the other an old companion they had not seen for years. The apes always spent more time looking at their former companion, research found.
nyti.ms/483kZIW

Justice Sandra Day O’Connor, the first woman on the Supreme Court, lay in repose on Monday in the court building where she served for 24 years. She was often the deciding vote in cases involving voting rights, religion and abortion. nyti.ms/3NuPb7G
The founder of the electric truck start-up Nikola Trevor Milton was sentenced to four years for fraud in a case that exposed the excesses in the EV business.

Breaking News: The actor Jonathan Majors was found guilty of assault and harassment for attacking his girlfriend in a car in March. His future in the film industry, already under threat, is now unclear.
Breaking News: Apple will pause selling new versions of the Apple Watch after it lost a patent dispute. The move could create a run on sales before Christmas.
A moderately strong, 5.9-magnitude earthquake struck in Northwestern China on Monday, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

The U.S. Transportation Department announced a $140 million fine against Southwest Airlines — by far the largest penalty imposed — over a meltdown last winter. The airline canceled nearly 17,000 flights and disrupted travel for about two million people. nyti.ms/3Tr6omp

A man who crashed his vehicle into a Secret Service vehicle protecting President Biden’s motorcade in Wilmington, Delaware, on Sunday was charged with driving under the influence of alcohol, local officials said. No one was injured in the accident.

In Gaza, family trees have been obliterated. “When I look at photos of my family on my phone, I cry to myself at night,” Nasser al-Astal said. More than 100 people in the Astal family alone have been killed in Israel's attacks, a spokesman for Gaza’s Health Ministry said.

The U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd Austin, was traveling on Sunday in the Middle East for a visit to Israel and three Persian Gulf nations as Biden administration officials push Israel to transition away from its large-scale military campaign in the Gaza Strip.

The flood-prone New York City neighborhood known as the Hole faces an uncertain future with climate change. Residents have faced snakes, spores growing inside their homes, sewage problems and more. “All of those extremes are already happening here,” Felicia Singh, a community activist, said.

Vladimir Putin has turned the exits of Western companies from Russia into an enrichment scheme. By dictating the terms of their departure, a New York Times investigation found, he has made a windfall for his government, Russia's elites and his war.
Florida Republicans removed almost all of the authority of their chairman, Christian Ziegler, as he faces a sexual assault investigation.

Jessica Vincent bought a vase at a Virginia thrift store in June for $3.99. The vase — which turned out to be part of a series that Carlo Scarpa, a renowned Italian architect, designed in the 1940s —  just sold at auction for $107,100.

Hidden in a corner of Central Park, if you walk by at just the right time of the year, a tree glitters with hundreds of photos, notes, ornaments and memorials to deceased pets. Here's the story of the Pet Memorial Christmas Tree. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/17/n...

Humanitarian aid began to enter the Gaza Strip through a second border crossing on Sunday morning, the UN said, as growing numbers of Gazans faced ceaseless hunger and cold and aid groups warned of widespread disease.

Jeff Roe, the chief strategist for the leading super PAC supporting Gov. Ron DeSantis’s presidential bid, resigned on Saturday night, the latest and perhaps most significant departure from the group, which has been consumed by turmoil in recent weeks.

From the moment a Chinese office worker arrived at his new job, he knew something was off. There was no job. He had been kidnapped and forced to work for an abusive online scam operation. Only by understanding how it worked could he hope to escape.

At least 61 migrants drowned in a shipwreck off Libya, an international migrant agency said on Saturday, adding to the unrelenting toll in the Mediterranean Sea as people in Africa flee famine, conflict and other upheavals.

New York City officials warned commuters to brace for disrupted travel conditions as a powerful storm was expected to batter the area with heavy winds and major flooding starting on Sunday and lasting into Monday.

Richard Hunt, a prolific sculptor whose towering metalwork became a mainstay of American public art, and whose 70-year career drew the attention of presidents from Lyndon B. Johnson to Barack Obama, died on Saturday. He was 88.

Mayim Bialik, who received an Emmy nomination for her work on “Jeopardy!” after the death of longtime host Alex Trebek, said on Friday that she would not return to the popular game show, leaving Ken Jennings as the sole host.
Homelessness surged this year to the highest level on record, the federal government reported on Friday. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/15/u...
Breaking News: Matthew Perry, the “Friends” actor, died from “the acute effects of ketamine,” the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner said in an autopsy report that was released on Friday.
Breaking News: A jury ordered Rudy Giuliani to pay $148 million for spreading lies that two election workers committed fraud in 2020.

Every year, our critics share their top film, TV, pop music and theater picks. This year, our readers critiqued those best-of-lists. See some of their suggestions, which included “Barbie” and Noah Kahan.
Breaking News: As Donald Trump left office, potentially sensitive material from the Russia investigation went missing, people familiar with the matter said.
Breaking News: Israeli troops mistakenly killed three Israeli hostages during combat with Hamas in the Gaza Strip, the military said.
Neanderthals were morning people, a new study suggests. And some humans today who like getting up early might credit genes they inherited from their Neanderthal ancestors.

The Belgian national railway company earned the equivalent of millions of dollars for deporting nearly 25,000 Jews and Roma, as well as forced laborers and members of the resistance, to Nazi concentration camps during World War II, a report has found.

Prince Harry’s phone was hacked by a British tabloid publisher, a court ruled in a major victory for the Duke of Sussex. The lawsuit is one of several cases he and his wife, Meghan, have brought against Britain’s tabloid press over privacy rights.

“It was fear at a level we didn’t know existed.”

Chen Goldstein-Almog and three of her children were kidnapped by Hamas on Oct. 7. Her husband and eldest daughter were killed in the attacks in Israel. Now freed, she recounted her seven-week ordeal.

A highly contagious, often deadly form of bird flu has taken a staggering toll on animals around the world over the past three years. Now it's surging again in Europe and North America. Here's what to know.

Breaking News: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will return 16 major Khmer-era artworks to Cambodia and Thailand that are associated with a dealer accused in 2019 of trafficking artifacts. nyti.ms/3NvLgYd

Brazil’s Congress approved a law on Thursday that threatens Indigenous people’s rights to most of the land they inhabit or claim, potentially opening vast territories to deforestation, farming and mining. The lawmakers overrode a veto by President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva.

Israeli forces have damaged or destroyed at least six cemeteries in the Gaza Strip, satellite imagery and video shows. The laws of armed conflict consider the intentional destruction of religious sites without military necessity a possible war crime.

A Republican-led campaign against researchers who study disinformation online has zeroed in on the most prominent U.S. government agency dedicated to countering propaganda and other information operations from terrorists and hostile nations.

Women are increasingly turning to IUDs as a form of contraception. It’s widely known that its insertion can be excruciatingly painful, but doctors have rarely discussed effective pain management options for it, experts said.

Congress passed legislation that directs the government to tell the public at least some of what it knows about UFOs within 25 years but stops short of more aggressive steps lawmakers sought to force greater transparency around unidentified phenomena.
Breaking News: The Biden administration told Israel it wanted the country to scale down its ground campaign in Gaza by the end of the year, officials said.
Breaking News: European Union leaders agreed to open membership negotiations with Ukraine, an important breakthrough for Kyiv as it tries to bolster support from its allies.

Breaking News: Republicans battling to hold onto the New York House seat vacated by George Santos selected Mazi Melesa Pilip, an Israeli military veteran, to run in a special election next year, party officials said.

Scientists have detected a poison among the spray of molecules emanating from Enceladus, a small moon of Saturn, adding to intrigue about the possibility of life there. “It’s the starting point for most theories on the origin of life,” one researcher said. nyti.ms/4aozY1J

Breaking News: The House passed an $886 billion military spending bill, clearing the measure for President Biden after pushing past a far-right revolt over abortion, transgender care and other issues.

EU leaders are meeting in Brussels for their quarterly summit with a goal of securing financial and political support for Ukraine. But Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary, who is seen as Vladimir Putin's closest ally, has suggested he will block both.
Breaking News: The House approved an impeachment inquiry into President Biden, as the GOP pushes ahead with a yearlong investigation that has turned up no evidence of wrongdoing.

Severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy is primarily driven by a single hormone, a new study found. The discovery could lead to better treatments, including for rare, life-threatening cases of it, researchers said. nyti.ms/473f9G9
The final witness in Donald Trump’s civil fraud trial in New York appeared on Wednesday as weeks of bitter and obscure arguments came to an end. A judge is expected to decide the case next year.

A legal-defense fund that was created by Donald Trump's allies to help pay the mounting legal bills of people connected to investigations into the former president has raised more than $1.6 million, a new filing showed.

Andre Braugher, who died on Monday at 61, adapted his no-nonsense, unflappable persona to great success across genres on television, in film and onstage. Here’s a look back at some of the roles that would go on to define the Emmy-winning actor’s career.

Gaza is facing a public health catastrophe because of overcrowding in the southern part of the enclave where people have gone to seek refuge from Israeli attacks and a collapsed health-care system after two months of intense warfare, a UN official said.
Breaking News: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged but signaled three cuts to borrowing costs in 2024. Follow live updates.

In “George Harrison: The Reluctant Beatle,” the biographer Philip Norman writes about the “paradox” of a man who was “unprecedentedly, ludicrously, suffocatingly famous while at the same time undervalued, overlooked and struggling for recognition.”

Andre Braugher's father wanted him to be an engineer and was furious when he gravitated to acting. After earning a Masters from Juilliard, he landed one of his first professional roles in the Oscar-winning 1989 film, “Glory.” Read his obituary here. nyti.ms/3NmL9hJ

Law enforcement agencies have obtained the prescription records of thousands of Americans from the country’s largest pharmacy chains — including CVS, Kroger and Rite Aid — without a warrant, a congressional inquiry found, raising concerns about how the companies handle patient privacy.

“Many said this could not be done.” Sultan Al Jaber, the oil executive in charge of U.N. climate talks, led negotiators from nearly 200 nations to a major new climate agreement that pledges to transition the global economy away from fossil fuels.

The Supreme Court will decide the scope of the obstruction charge central to the federal election-interference case against Donald Trump and hundreds of prosecutions arising from the assault on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/13/u...

Breaking News: Hunter Biden offered again to testify publicly in the impeachment inquiry against his father, defying a subpoena to appear privately. He has objected to providing private testimony, saying he fears Republicans will selectively leak his remarks and try to distort what he says.

The Supreme Court agreed to rule on access to a commonly used abortion pill, the justices announced on Wednesday. It is the first major case involving abortion on its docket since it overturned the constitutional right to an abortion more than a year ago. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/13/u...
Breaking News: Tesla recalled more than two million vehicles to fix a function designed to ensure drivers are focused when using its Autopilot feature.

The Vatican said on Tuesday that Catholic families may ask to preserve “a minimal part of the ashes” of a relative in a place of significance to the deceased, softening a previous mandate that ashes could be kept only in “sacred spaces” like cemeteries.
Breaking News: New York’s highest court ordered the state to redraw its congressional map, clearing the way for Democrats to tilt a key battleground leftward.

A group of current and former prisoners sued the state of Alabama on Tuesday, saying that its system of prison labor is a modern form of slavery that forces them to work for the benefit of government agencies and private businesses. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/12/u...

Free-ranging domestic cats, including feral ones, eat more than 2,000 species, some of them imperiled, a new study found. The research — which included surprise species like camels, cows and sea turtles — has raised concerns about the ecological fallout.

More than two-thirds of the world’s countries agreed to retool the global food system at COP28, the UN's climate summit. Hunger has risen in the last three years, as Covid and the Russian invasion of Ukraine have upended the food and energy supply chain.
Ukraine's president, Volodymyr Zelensky, hit a wall of resistance from Republicans as he began a visit to Washington to plead for more aid to help his country fight Russian invaders.

Price increases in the U.S. remained moderate in November, the latest sign that inflation has cooled substantially from its June 2022 peak, data released on Tuesday showed. www.nytimes.com/2023/12/11/b...
Wu-Tang Clan will begin a Las Vegas residency in February as the city hosts its first Super Bowl, the Grammy-nominated hip-hop group announced on Tuesday.
A stage musical about Paddington, the well-traveled bear known for his floppy red hat and love for orange marmalade sandwiches, is set to open in Britain in 2025.

Kanye West, now known as Ye, previewed “Vultures,” his first album since he made a string of antisemitic comments last year, at a listening party that streamed with technical difficulties. He said the joint album with Ty Dolla Sign will be released Friday.

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is meeting with U.S. lawmakers on Tuesday before a visit to the White House as the chances of Congress passing an aid package for Ukraine's fight against Russia have grown bleak. Follow live updates.

Ukraine’s largest mobile operator, Kyivstar, said it had come under a powerful cyberattack on Tuesday that knocked out service and affected internet access for millions of people. The country relies on phone alerts to warn of close Russian bombardments.

“A significant change in approach from the United States government is needed today to pull Gaza back from this abyss,” the heads of six of the world’s leading humanitarian groups write in a guest essay.

The Biden administration said on Monday that it is looking into reports that Israel illegally used white phosphorus supplied by the U.S. in October in Lebanon. Israel’s military said that it complies with international law and denied using the weapon illegally.

For months, donors waged a campaign against the University of Pennsylvania’s president, Elizabeth Magill, who resigned on Saturday. Penn’s board was divided until her disastrous appearance at a congressional hearing on antisemitism tipped the scale.

Breaking News: A pregnant woman at the center of a legal fight over her rights to an abortion in Texas despite its bans will leave the state for the procedure rather than wait for a ruling from the Texas Supreme Court.

Nearly 700 Harvard faculty members signed a statement in support of the university’s president, Claudine Gay, amid calls that she resign for her answers at a hearing on antisemitism. The petition organizers focused their appeal on academic freedom.

After a tomato vanished from the International Space Station, the NASA astronaut Frank Rubio said he spent hours looking for it, seeking to prove he had not eaten it. Months later, his name was cleared. “We found the tomato,” another astronaut said.

The future of Harvard University’s president, Claudine Gay, was on the line on Monday as the school’s governing body met amid calls for her removal following the widely criticized comments she made at a congressional hearing about antisemitism on campus.

Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida accused former Donald Trump of “cowardice” for refusing to participate in the Republican presidential primary debates after the former president bragged about debating Hillary Clinton in 2016.
Breaking News: The special counsel in Donald Trump’s election case asked the Supreme Court to decide if he is immune from prosecution, urging unusual speed.

Shannon Stillwell, a co-defendant of the rapper Young Thug in the racketeering and gang conspiracy case currently underway in Atlanta, was stabbed in jail on Sunday night, his lawyer said, delaying the blockbuster trial.
The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not hear a First Amendment challenge to a Washington State law banning conversion therapy.

More people in the U.S. than ever spend half or more of their income on rent, taking away from essential needs like food and medicine, destroying the ability to save, causing stress and leaving some without a home to call their own. nyti.ms/3RgXS6O

Marvin Haynes, who was sentenced in 2005 to life in prison, maintained he was wrongfully convicted of murder after a flawed investigation by the Minneapolis Police Department. On Monday, prosecutors concluded he was right — setting the 36-year-old free.

Poland’s newly elected Parliament rejected a long-shot effort by right-wing forces on Monday to stay in power despite losing a general election in October. Donald Tusk, a former prime minister and leader of the main opposition party, is set to take over.

A family in a small New York town holds the Guinness World Record for the most lights on a residential property, with 720,420. For the visitors who come to see them, the decorations are supersized holiday cheer. For some neighbors, it’s a holiday nightmare. nyti.ms/3tgrfxZ
As climate change intensifies, a quarter of the world’s freshwater fish are at risk of extinction, according to a new assessment which found that the biggest threat to the species was pollution.
“Barbie” led the Golden Globe nominations with nine, followed by “Oppenheimer” with eight. In the television categories, “Succession” had the most with nine.

As President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine heads to Washington to appeal for more military support from the U.S., the Russian military targeted Kyiv with the most intense bombardment of ballistic missiles in months on Monday.

Communities across the U.S. are fueling a secondary arms market by giving seized and surrendered guns to disposal services that destroy one part and resell the rest, often with no background check required, a New York Times investigation found.
Decades after the unexplained deaths of two American climbers in Argentina, a camera belonging to one of them was found in the snow. The film held astonishing images, but the mystery endures.

Donald Trump's pardon of a drug smuggler named Jonathan Braun had broader implications than previously known, an investigation by The New York Times found. It raises new questions about how Trump would use his clemency powers in a second term.
Nadia Mohamed, the 27-year-old mayor-elect of St. Louis Park, Minnesota, will become the country's first elected Somali-American mayor. Her win, she says, "is just the first chapter."

Life in besieged Gaza revolves around a daily struggle to find food and water. Families are burning doors and window frames to cook what they can scrounge. Diarrhea, scabies and lice are ripping through the population, hitting children particularly hard.
Pentagon researchers say weapons like shoulder-fired rockets expose troops who fire them to blast waves far above safety limits, but they remain in wide use.
Two days after the first group of 13 hostages was released to Israel, details of the nearly 50 days they and others spent as captives of armed groups in Gaza have begun to emerge.
Breaking News: Hamas released 17 more hostages under a deal with Israel, including a 4-year-old girl who is a dual Israeli and U.S. citizen.

Large outbreaks of diseases that primarily kill children are spreading around the world after disruptions to health systems during the Covid-19 pandemic that have left more than 60 million children without a single dose of standard childhood vaccines.

Australia's fire season is well underway. It is expected to be the worst fire season since the summer of 2019-2020, when nearly 500 people died from direct fire exposure and smoke inhalation, and tens of thousands of acres were charred.

Beyoncé is one of the most private superstars. “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé” pulls back the curtain — a little. Here are four takeaways from the Los Angeles premiere of the concert documentary on Saturday.

More than three dozen members of Congress have already said they are planning to leave their seats, setting the stage for major turnover in the 2024 election. Here’s a look at the retirements that have been announced so far.
At least one American citizen could be among the group of hostages Hamas is set to release on Sunday, Jake Sullivan, President Biden’s national security adviser, said on CBS’s “Face the Nation.”

A Ukrainian strike on a power station in Russian-held territory in eastern Ukraine overnight cut power to towns and cities, the pro-Russian authorities there said on Sunday, less than a day after Moscow launched a record number of attack drones toward Kyiv.
Breaking News: Hamas released a second round of Israeli hostages after mediators helped overcome a delay.

People in Ireland are celebrating Caio Benicio, a Brazilian delivery driver who intervened in a stabbing that caused one of the worst anti-immigrant riots in recent memory, by buying him a pint. On Saturday, donors raised over 330,000 euros, about $350,000.
Breaking News: Hamas said it was delaying a second round of hostage releases, citing a problem with the delivery of aid to Gaza.
In less than two months, more than twice as many women and children have been reported killed in Gaza than in Ukraine after two years of war.

An initial investigation of a speeding vehicle that crashed and exploded at a U.S.-Canada border crossing near Niagara Falls on Wednesday found no evidence that the crash was related to terrorism, Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York said.

A four-day cease-fire between Israel and Hamas — the first extended break in almost seven weeks of war — will begin on Thursday, officials on both sides said. But an Israeli official said the exchange of prisoners for hostages will not begin before Friday.
In the Dutch elections, the party of Geert Wilders, a far-right, anti-immigrant figure, appears set to win, according to exit polls. The result could send shock waves through Europe.

More than 30 children were abducted from their homes and taken to Gaza during the Hamas-led assault on Oct. 7. Some are expected to be among the first hostages released in the coming days under a cease-fire, but the wait is straining their families.

Births increased in every state with an abortion ban, an analysis of preliminary data since Roe v. Wade was overturned shows. The biggest increases were in states where women had to travel the farthest to reach an abortion clinic.
The head of the main super PAC backing Ron DeSantis resigned, as infighting among the presidential candidate’s allies reached a breaking point.

Breaking News: Two people died and a U.S. Border Patrol officer was injured when a vehicle exploded at a U.S.-Canada border crossing near Niagara Falls. The cause of the explosion has not been determined. Follow live updates.

Deep-frying a Thanksgiving turkey is not just a stunt — it’s the best way to cook it, says a New York Times Food reporter. With the right equipment, some caution and a lot of peanut oil, it will yield the juiciest, crispiest bird. Watch how to do it here.

A mysterious respiratory illness that has been sickening dogs continues to spread across the U.S. while veterinarians try to determine its causes and the best methods for treating it. Dogs in at least seven states have been infected. nyti.ms/3uuR5i8

An explosion involving a vehicle entering the U.S. on Wednesday caused the closure of the Rainbow Bridge, a border crossing between the U.S. and Canada, the authorities said. The cause of the blast and whether there were casualties were unknown.

Usually, a belly-up fish isn’t long for this world. But video evidence from the deep ocean suggests that some species of anglerfish — the nightmarish deep-sea fish with bioluminescent lures — live their whole lives upside down.

In Opinion

"What does it mean to be creative when the means by which we are creative have vanished? In my case: words, ideas, feelings, memories," the novelist Kelly Barnhill, who experienced a traumatic brain injury in 2021, writes.

Powder-filled envelopes — including some that appear to have been laced with fentanyl — were mailed to election offices in five states. They're a sign of what some officials say is a rise in threats to the safety of election workers as 2024 approaches.

After Israel and Hamas agreed to a temporary cease-fire and the release of some hostages and prisoners, negotiators on Wednesday were trying to work out key details of the deal, including when it will start and who will be included. Follow live updates.

In Opinion

"It is imperative that we do our best to provide Israelis and Palestinians with a thoughtful response that maps out a realistic path to addressing the reality we face today," Sen. Bernie Sanders writes in a guest essay.

Lebanese officials said three people, including two journalists, were killed in an Israeli strike on Tuesday in southern Lebanon, as cross-border clashes intensified between Israel and the armed group Hezbollah. Israel's military said it was under review.
The influential Iowa evangelical leader Bob Vander Plaats plans to endorse Ron DeSantis for the Republican presidential nomination on Tuesday, according to a person familiar with his decision.

This Thanksgiving could be the busiest one for travel in decades, with TSA expecting to screen 2.9 million passengers on Nov. 26, as airfare and gas prices drop. But rain and cold could pose obstacles in parts of the U.S. through early Wednesday.

Federal Reserve officials are contemplating whether they will need to raise interest rates again to cool the economy and ensure that rapid inflation will fully fade. Minutes from their meeting earlier this month laid out the contours of that debate.

Plains, Georgia, a city of about 550 people, figured into just about every part of the life Rosalynn Carter, who died Sunday at 96. Residents mourned losing a constant presence who, along with her husband the former president, came to shape the community.
Breaking News: The founder of the cryptocurrency exchange Binance agreed to plead guilty to money laundering violations and step down from the company.

The rise in use of killer drones on battlefields worldwide has ignited debate over how or whether to regulate their use and spurred concerns about the prospect of eventually turning life-or-death decisions over to artificial intelligence.

The families of 9/11 victims have been leaving memory stones and seashells for years at Guantánamo Bay, where the men accused of conspiring in the hijackings are held. The messages for the nearly 3,000 killed have become a way to reflect individual loss.

Ukraine commemorated the 10th anniversary of the Maidan protests on Tuesday, the popular uprising that toppled a pro-Russia president, showcased the nation’s embrace of European values and foreshadowed the current conflict with Moscow.

Joe Biden’s campaign is betting that once voters view the 2024 election as a choice between him and Donald Trump, who remains highly polarizing, they will set aside their reservations about the president and fall in line behind him.

In Opinion

We spoke to 12 Democrats on what they think it means to be in their party. Most of the group still believed that Democrats remained the party of the people — but it has rarely delivered results.

In the two years since its emergence, Omicron, the Covid-19 variant, has proved to be not only staggeringly infectious — but an evolutionary marvel, challenging many assumptions virologists had before the pandemic.

Israel and Hamas appeared on Tuesday to be close to a brief pause in their 46-day war to allow for the release of some hostages held in Gaza in exchange for some Palestinian prisoners held by Israel. Follow for live updates.

Javier Milei, a far-right political outsider with little governing experience, has been elected Argentina’s next president, and is now tasked with guiding one of Latin America’s largest economies out of one of its worst economic crises.

The Biden administration is offering Americans another round of free at-home coronavirus tests through the Postal Service. Here is how households can order four free tests through a federal website, starting Monday.

When Ukraine’s top military commander said recently the war with Russia had reached a “stalemate,” it created an impression in some areas of a war in stasis. But for the Ukrainian soldiers and medics on the frontlines, it does not feel the least bit static.
Breaking News: A federal appeals court signaled it would most likely keep a version of the gag order in Donald Trump’s federal election case but may narrow its scope.

Twenty-eight premature babies who had been in intensive care at the embattled Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza — and had become a symbol of civilian suffering — were transported across the Egyptian border for medical care on Monday, Al Qahera News said. nyti.ms/3G9N84M

The Bergdorf blonde is now taking meetings at the Regency Hotel. Parvin Klein, the veteran colorist who perfected an iconic shade of blonde, has painted her last highlight at the Bergdorf Goodman department store salon.
Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas endorsed Donald Trump on Sunday in an appearance near the southern border, echoing Trump’s talk about an existential crisis of illegal immigration.
Breaking News: Israel released video of what it said was a Hamas tunnel under Al-Shifa Hospital, seeking to bolster its claims that the group used the complex, which Israeli forces stormed last week.
Breaking News: Rosalynn Carter, the former first lady who helped propel Jimmy Carter from rural Georgia to the White House, has died at 96.

Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour has faced tragedy and mishaps during a three-day stretch of concerts in Brazil. As the tour’s second show in Rio de Janeiro approached on Sunday night, fans grappled with extreme heat, ruined travel plans and disappointment.

A mother spent months calling the police in Jackson, Mississippi, for help finding her 37-year-old son. Investigators knew but didn't tell her, records show, that an off-duty officer driving an SUV had fatally struck him on the day that she last saw him.

Some engineers are looking to artificial intelligence to help build more resilient infrastructure projects for less money. But experts caution against embracing the technology too quickly when it is largely unregulated and its payoffs remain largely unproven.

The FBI faulted agents in 2019 for misusing their guns in two separate shootings, each an exceedingly rare internal finding of violations of its lethal force policy, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.

Israel and Hamas are close to reaching a deal to pause fighting for multiple days so that hostages can be released, but Jon Finer, President Biden’s deputy national security adviser, warned on Sunday that the fragile negotiations could still fall apart.

Thirty-one premature babies in extremely critical condition were evacuated from Al-Shifa Hospital on Sunday amid Israel’s push to seize the biggest hospital in the Gaza Strip and will be taken to Egypt for treatment, officials said.

Assisted-living centers have become an appealing retirement option for those who can no longer live independently as an alternative to the institutional feel of a nursing home. But their cost is so crushingly high that most Americans can’t afford them.

Sam Altman's ouster from OpenAI has drawn attention to a longtime rift in the artificial intelligence community between people who believe AI is the biggest business opportunity in a generation and others who worry that moving too fast could be dangerous.

Voters in Argentina will choose whether to elect Javier Milei — a far-right libertarian who has drawn comparisons to Donald Trump — or the center-left economy minister, Sergio Massa, to be its next president on Sunday. Here's what to know.
The WHO said overnight that it had visited Gaza's largest hospital, Al-Shifa, and described it as a "death zone," days after the Israeli military stormed the complex.

Casey McIntyre, a 38-year-old woman with ovarian cancer, started a campaign to help people pay off their medical debt. The funds raised in the week since she died are expected to pay off more than $20 million in debt, an official said.

The sudden ouster of Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, set off a guessing game about what brought down one of the industry’s biggest stars, at a time when everything seemed to be going his way.

George Brown, a founding member and drummer of the group Kool & the Gang, died on Thursday at 74. Brown, known as Funk, was a key contributor to several of the band's biggest hits, including “Ladies Night,” “Jungle Boogie” and “Celebration.”
Breaking News: Disney, Apple and Lionsgate halted ads on X as Elon Musk faced a furor over his endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on the social media app, formerly known as Twitter.

The 24th annual Latin Grammy Awards took place in Spain — the first time the ceremony was outside the U.S — where the top awards went to women from Latin America, including Karol G, Shakira and Natalia Lafourcade. Our critic reflects on the evening.
Israeli soldiers found the body of a second Israeli held hostage near Al-Shifa Hospital, the Israeli military said on Friday, as its forces continued to scour the facility.

Jordan’s foreign minister has signaled that his country, one of the driest in the world, will not sign a new water-for-energy deal with Israel. He said Israel’s assault on Gaza has “proved that there is no way there could be any natural peaceful relations.”

After Taylor Swift fans discovered Travis Kelce's mundane tweets about Olive Garden and squirrels, which appear to have been posted in his early 20s, other posts proved to be more troubling. It's spurred debate online over how critically celebrities should be judged for decade-old content.
Breaking News: The Republican chairman of the House ethics panel moved to expel Representative George Santos of New York from Congress, setting the stage for a vote after Thanksgiving.
The music mogul Sean Combs, also known as Diddy or Puff Daddy, was accused of rape and abuse in a lawsuit filed by the singer Cassie, his former girlfriend.

Breaking News: Workers at the three big U.S. automakers — General Motors, Ford and Stellantis — backed new contracts that deliver hefty wage increases and other gains not seen in decades. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/16/b...

$6,000 at Ferragamo; regular cosmetic treatments labeled “Botox” on internal campaign records; and even small purchases on OnlyFans: These are some of the expenses Rep. George Santos made with his donors' campaign money, House ethics investigators found.

Breaking News: Mayor Eric Adams announced painful cuts to the New York City budget that would freeze police hiring and close libraries on Sunday. He warned that more cuts would be necessary without additional federal funding to manage the migrant crisis.

The Gaza Strip is again in a communications blackout that is affecting most of the more than two million people in the enclave amid Israel’s ground operation and bombardment. Two major Palestinian mobile networks cited fuel shortages for the outage.

An Arab-American runner who participated in a photo shoot to promote the New York City Marathon said she was cropped out of a Lululemon media campaign because of her identity and support for Palestinians. Lululemon said it was a mistake.
Breaking News: The man who broke into Nancy Pelosi’s home and attacked her husband with a hammer last year has been convicted of federal crimes. He faces a possible life sentence.

Finland said on Thursday that it was closing part of its border with Russia after a dramatic increase in migrant crossings that it blamed on Moscow, the latest sign of deteriorating relations between the neighbors since the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
Breaking News: UAW union members at General Motors have ratified a new contract in a closely contested vote that followed weeks of walkouts. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/16/b...

Nikki Haley will return to Iowa for a series of presidential campaign events starting on Thursday as her battle with Ron DeSantis to become Donald Trump’s nearest rival reaches a fever pitch, just two months before the critical first caucuses.

A top ultramarathoner who rode in a car during a race has been banned for a year from competing or coaching in Britain. Joasia Zakrzewski acknowledged that in April she traveled by car for two and a half miles of a 50-mile race from Manchester to Liverpool.

A storm system that unleashed up to 10 inches of heavy rainfall over parts of southeastern Florida and cut power to thousands of people eased early on Thursday, and moved east away from the coast, meteorologists said.
President Xi Jinping of China addressed executives from Apple, Nike and others on Wednesday night in San Francisco. Elon Musk appeared during cocktail hour.
Breaking News: The House Ethics Committee found “substantial evidence” that Representative George Santos of New York violated federal law, ending a nearly nine-month investigation.

As many as two million formerly incarcerated people in New York will have their convictions sealed if they remain out of trouble for a set time under the Clean Slate Act. 

Gov. Kathy Hochul is expected to sign the legislation into law on Thursday.

Christopher Wray, the FBI director, said on Wednesday that the bureau had opened a slew of investigations into Hamas as it tries to thwart potential attacks and stymie financial support for the militant group.

Donald Trump's lawyers on Wednesday called for a mistrial in the civil fraud case against him in New York, arguing that the judge and his law clerk were politically biased against him. The judge is expected to reject the long-shot legal effort.

Nikki Haley and Ron DeSantis have attacked each other with misleading claims as they battle to be the leading alternative to the Republican Party’s presidential front-runner, Donald Trump. Here’s a fact check on some of their claims.

Students at Columbia University rallied after the school’s decision to suspend two pro-Palestinian student groups through the end of the semester. And on Wednesday, roughly 200 faculty members walked out to protest the decision.

The House Ethics Committee will not call for Rep. George Santos’s expulsion as a result of its nearly nine-month investigation, the panel’s chair said on Wednesday. The lengthy investigation will conclude this week, leaving his fate in the hands of his fellow House members.

President Biden met with President Xi Jinping of China in California for the APEC Summit on Wednesday. Xi told Biden that their countries were very different but should be “fully capable of rising above differences.”

Follow our live updates. nyti.ms/3ujLdYY

"Just weeks into his new job, Speaker Mike Johnson has already learned a valuable, if painful, lesson: Being an uncompromising conservative hard-liner is much easier from the backbenches than it is from the leadership suites," Carl Hulse writes.
Nasser Hospital in the city of Khan Younis is running out of beds, disinfectant and basic painkillers. Our photographer explained this image that shows the brutal reality inside a Gaza hospital.
Breaking News: The House passed legislation to avert a government shutdown after Democrats rescued a temporary spending plan that many Republicans opposed.

The House is preparing to vote on a stopgap funding measure to keep the federal government open into next year. The bill needs a supermajority, two-thirds, to pass. The deadline to fund the government and avert a shutdown is midnight Friday. Follow live.
A New York landlord was arrested and charged with murdering his tenants on Tuesday after he confessed to fatally stabbing three people in his Queens home, the police said.

Israeli forces have continued to advance deep into Gaza City, fighting street battles with Hamas and surrounding hospitals, where conditions are increasingly dire. Tracks of Israeli military vehicles are visible in commercially available satellite imagery. nyti.ms/3SM39pn

21 children with cancer have been evacuated from Gaza to hospitals in Egypt and Jordan over the past 10 days, according to aid workers. But at least 30 other patients have not made it out. Inside the mission to rescue cancer-stricken children from Gaza.

Thousands of people gathered on the National Mall in Washington on Tuesday to show solidarity with Israel and its response to Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack. The rally, called the March for Israel, comes after large protests against the country’s military campaign in Gaza.

The Inverted Jenny, a stamp issued by the U.S. Post Office in 1918 of a biplane, was accidentally printed upside down. It would go on to become a collector’s item. Originally priced at 24 cents, one of them recently sold for more than $2 million.
Breaking News: A former campaign aide to Representative George Santos of New York admitted to impersonating a House staff member in a fund-raising scheme and pleaded guilty to wire fraud.

Mike Johnson played an influential role in national efforts to reassert Christian conservative values as a lawyer and a Republican state lawmaker. Here’s how battling a Louisiana abortion clinic set in motion his path to becoming House speaker.

Booths, a small grocery chain in northern England, announced that it will be getting rid of its self-checkouts in nearly all but two of its 28 stores, bucking a trend that has remade retail shopping around the world over the last 20 years. nyti.ms/3MDrFor

Speaker Mike Johnson posted on social media in 2015 that Donald Trump was unfit to serve and could be a danger as president. Johnson, who was a state lawmaker at the time, told The New York Times that he made his comments before he personally knew Trump.

An increasing number of House Democrats privately indicated that they would support Speaker Mike Johnson’s measure to extend government funding into early next year to avert a shutdown. A vote is expected late Tuesday afternoon.

Israeli military vehicles arrived at the gates of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City where fuel, medicine and food are running out. “I’m watching patients die in front of my eyes, and I can’t provide them the slightest bit of help,” one doctor said.

Representative Rashida Tlaib, the only Palestinian American in Congress, who was censured by the House, represents Jewish and Arab American communities with strong views on the war. We spoke to people in her Detroit area district.

After telling passengers she was nominated for two Grammys, Bobbi Storm began singing on a Delta Air Lines flight. She was then threatened with being removed from the plane after refusing to stop because she was “doing what the Lord” told her to do.
New York could soon stop requiring many high school students to take Regents exams, a major step in an overhaul of the state’s graduation system.

Breaking News: The Supreme Court said on Monday that it had issued an ethics code for the justices after months of increasing pressure to adopt one following a series of revelations about undisclosed property deals and gifts.

More than 125,000 Israeli evacuees have been evacuated from their communities near the borders with Lebanon and Gaza, where Hamas massacred Israeli civilians and soldiers a month ago. It's the largest internal displacement in Israel's history.

Israeli military vehicles advanced on Monday to the gates of the besieged Al-Shifa hospital complex as medical staff painted a calamitous picture of conditions there. “The situation here is catastrophic in every sense of the word,” one nurse said. nyti.ms/3R6vzsZ

Chevron said Monday that it resumed production of natural gas from a platform in Israeli waters on instructions from the government. Israel’s Ministry of Energy ordered the U.S. energy giant to halt production at the Tamar platform after the Hamas attacks.

James Cleverly will move from his position leading Britain's Foreign Office to become the country’s home secretary. He will inherit a department dealing with the fallout from Suella Braverman's face-off with the police.

Donald Trump Jr. is testifying again in the civil fraud case against his father and the family business by New York’s attorney general. This time, defense lawyers called him to begin their arguments in the trial. Follow our live updates.

A Canadian search-and-rescue group said it had conducted two missions recently after hikers “may have sought to follow” a nonexistent trail on Google Maps. The group advised hikers to use a paper map and compass instead.

“The thrill of it is amazing.” Amy Siewe teaches people how to find and euthanize invasive Burmese pythons in the Florida Everglades. The state has organized competitions to reward hunters who catch and humanely kill the most snakes. nyti.ms/3MFgY58

Amid a crisis in affordable housing, the century-old ideas of Henry George have gained a new currency. His argument might sound wonky — tax the value of land but not improvements atop it — but it made him a celebrity in the 1890s.

As Israeli troops move deeper into Gaza City, they have closed in on hospitals, where displaced civilians have also sought refuge. The Palestinian Red Crescent said on Sunday that Al-Quds Hospital in Gaza City was “no longer operational.”

This plant has made nearly all U.S. military rifle cartridges since Vietnam. It's also made billions of rounds for the commercial market, a New York Times found, including those used in some of the U.S.'s most deadly mass shootings.

A pond in Hawaii became a social media spectacle this week after turning bubble-gum pink. However, experts said the new hue, seen at the Kealia Pond National Wildlife Refuge on Maui, was not just a photo opportunity but an indicator of environmental stress. nyti.ms/3QAazt5

Operations at Gaza’s main hospital were showing signs of collapse on Saturday, with the health authorities describing power outages, shortages of water and medicine and a crisis in treating seriously wounded patients and vulnerable children.

The leaders of Iran and Saudi Arabia, regional rivals who restored diplomatic ties after years of hostility, met on Saturday and called for an immediate cease-fire in Gaza as well as the unconditional delivery of humanitarian aid to the besieged enclave.
Lawyers for Donald Trump have told a judge that she should permit his trial on federal charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election to be televised live from the courtroom.

The UN has verified more than 250 attacks on health care facilities in Gaza and the West Bank, including hospitals, clinics, ambulances and patients, with five hospitals hit in the last week alone, according to the director general of the UN's WHO.

Nearly 30 people took refuge inside a bomb shelter on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the bunker near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection. But when Hamas assailants attacked, the safehold became a deathtrap for those inside.
The Rev. Stephen C. Lee says he was pastoring to people in Georgia after the 2020 election. The indictment says he was pressuring an elections worker.

Ukraine’s military said on Saturday that it had shot down a Russian ballistic missile hurtling toward Kyiv, the first such attack on the capital in weeks, while cities across the country were targeted by a Russian air barrage that damaged several buildings.
Armistice Day, which originally marked the end of World War I, was broadened in the U.S. in the 1950s to honor all veterans. Here’s a look at the history of Veterans Day.

The family whose story was chronicled in the Netflix documentary “Take Care of Maya” was awarded $261 million in damages from a hospital after a jury found it liable for charges including medical negligence and false imprisonment. nyti.ms/46aYEro

Victoria Monét scored seven Grammy nominations, the second-most this year. Hazel, her 2-year-old daughter, became the youngest Grammy nominee ever for her feature appearance — alongside Earth, Wind & Fire — on her mom's song “Hollywood.”

Davide Renne, the Italian fashion designer and former head of women’s wear at Gucci, where he worked for 20 years, died on Friday, just nine days after becoming the creative director of Moschino. He was 46. nyti.ms/3suej7i

Sofia Coppola’s “Priscilla” has built a narrative that so many young women gravitate to, the film critic Emily Yoshida writes: “It’s OK, even honorable, to be a sad girl. And there’s no good reason sad girls can’t just stay sad.”

Senator Joe Manchin's decision to not seek re-election means Republicans are almost certain to take control of his West Virginia seat. And that makes Democrats' path to holding the Senate even rockier than it already was. nyti.ms/3sCFZqx

A small group of Republicans in Congress — concerned that their party’s opposition to abortion rights has alienated women — are trying to pivot away from an anti-abortion message. A much larger coalition, including the party’s leaders, are doubling down.
Experts answer some of the most frequently asked questions about seasonal affective disorder.

A maze of tunnels built by Hamas extends below the Gaza Strip. No outsider has an exact map of the network. But photos and video and reports from people who have been in the tunnels suggest the basic outlines of the system and how it is used.
SZA, Taylor Swift and Olivia Rodrigo are among the top contenders for the 66th annual Grammy Awards. The “Barbie” soundtrack has a total of 11 nominations.

A former Tesla employee, who said he was harassed, threatened and eventually fired after expressing safety concerns, leaked personnel records and data about the company’s Autopilot driver-assistance software, including thousands of accident reports.

Pope Francis has made clear that transgender people can be baptized, serve as godparents and be witnesses at church weddings, furthering his vision of a more inclusive Catholic church, in a new Vatican document.

The Israeli military has limited time in Gaza before anger among Arabs in the region and frustration in the U.S. and other countries over the civilian death toll constrain Israel’s goal of eradicating Hamas, U.S. officials said.
Recent surveillance orders by the Mexico City attorney general's office read like a political power list. Many in the country say they were targeted for political reasons.

The Fed chair Jerome Powell on Thursday expressed little urgency to increase interest rates again. But he made clear that officials remain willing to adjust policy further if doing so proves necessary to cool the economy and fully restrain inflation.
Senator Joe Manchin of West Virginia said on Thursday that he would not seek re-election, threatening Democrats’ hold on the Senate.

Thousands of earthquakes recorded over the past few days have led to the pre-emptive closure of the Blue Lagoon, an iconic tourist destination and a geothermal spa in Iceland. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/09/w...

Breaking News: Jezebel, the pioneering feminist website, is shutting down after 16 years of publishing commentary and news focused on women. The layoffs will affect 23 people, the chief executive of G/O Media, the site's parent company, said.

More than 100 letters meant for French sailors were never delivered. They went unopened for nearly 250 years until a historian found them in Britain’s archives, revealing a treasure trove of intimate details about romance and daily life in mid-18th-century France.

Do you know what a gyat is? What about a rizzler? And how, precisely, does one pay a Fanum tax?

Welcome to the language of Gen Alpha — the cohort coming up right behind Gen Z that is bamboozling its elders with terms all their own.

After 5-year-old Prince McCree disappeared on Oct. 25, the police in Milwaukee asked state officials to issue an Amber Alert. The state denied the request, and Prince was found dead the next day. Now, his family is asking why no alert was issued.

Breaking News: The kidnapped father of Luis Díaz, a Colombian soccer star who plays for Liverpool, has been freed, Colombian officials said. He was abducted 12 days ago by a guerrilla group called the National Liberation Army.

Nikki Haley told Vivek Ramaswamy, “You’re just scum,” at the Republican presidential debate. Donald Trump skipped it for a third time in a row.
