Israel nearly reached a deal with Hamas to release up to 50 hostages days before launching an invasion of Gaza, Arab and Western officials say. Talks have resumed, but hopes for a quick release have faded.

Republican lawmakers are again calling to ban TikTok amid accusations that the popular short-form video app is amplifying pro-Palestinian and anti-Israel videos through its algorithmic feed. ByteDance, which owns TikTok, has refuted the claims.

Meta has introduced a new policy to grapple with AI’s effects on political advertising. Starting next year, Meta will require political advertisers to disclose when they had used AI software in ads to synthetically depict people and events.
The FBI and local police departments searched a swath of central New Jersey on Wednesday for a man wanted in connection with the Jan. 6 riot at the U.S. Capitol.
Google has long been a hub for employee activism, including over the company’s business with Israel. But workers looking to express support for Palestinians say they face hostility.

Breaking News: House Republicans issued subpoenas demanding testimony from Hunter and James Biden, the president’s son and brother, as they hunt for evidence to try to build an impeachment case against him.

A significant shift in donor contributions to nonprofits fighting climate change in recent years has left some of the nation’s biggest environmental organizations facing critical shortfalls in programs on toxic chemicals, radioactive contamination and wildlife protection.
Breaking News: The FDA approved an obesity drug, already used for diabetes, that will be a direct competitor to Wegovy. The drug is called tirzepatide and will be sold under the name Zepbound.

Secretary of State Antony Blinken said Wednesday that Gaza should be unified with the West Bank under the Palestinian Authority once the war ends, a signal from the Biden administration about what it would like to see at the end of the Israel-Hamas war.

The world’s fossil fuel giants, together, are on course this decade to produce twice the amount of fossil fuels than a critical global warming threshold allows, a new report found. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/08/c...
The New York Times now has more than 10 million subscribers, the company said on Wednesday in its third-quarter report, edging closer to its goal of 15 million by the end of 2027.

Hamas leaders say they attacked Israel because they feared the Palestinian cause was slipping away and they needed to “change the equation.”

“I hope that the state of war with Israel will become permanent,” a Hamas leader told The New York Times.

Andy Beshear's re-election as the Democratic governor of Kentucky on Tuesday followed a campaign that could serve as a blueprint for Democrats, who for years have seen rural states slipping ever further out of reach.

Citigroup employees labeled a group of roughly 80,000 Armenian-Americans living near Los Angeles as “bad guys” and secretly denied them fair access to the bank’s credit card products, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau said on Wednesday. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/08/b...

Vivek Ramaswamy is both deeply in touch with his Indian heritage and adamant that the growing focus on diversity in the U.S. has come at the cost of national unity. The first-time presidential candidate's message is geared toward a Republican electorate that is heavily white and Christian.

Yusef Salaam, who was one of five Black and Latino teenagers convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park and exonerated decades later, was elected to represent Harlem in the New York City Council on Tuesday night. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/08/n...

Kimberly Mata-Rubio, whose daughter was killed in the mass shooting at an elementary school in Uvalde, Texas, lost a special election to become mayor. She'd demanded more accountability for the slow police response and advocated stronger gun laws. nyti.ms/3QPV6GG

Gov. Andy Beshear of Kentucky won a second term on Tuesday, earning a noteworthy victory for a Democrat in a deeply conservative state. One of the most popular governors in the U.S., Beshear led in polls throughout the at times bitterly contested race. nyti.ms/462ESOD

Ohio voters approved a ballot measure enshrining a right to abortion in the State Constitution on Tuesday. Issue 1, as the ballot measure is known, had become the most-watched race in the off-year U.S. elections. nyti.ms/47e8p98

Cherelle Parker, a longtime state and local elected official, was elected mayor of Philadelphia on Tuesday, making her the first woman voted into the city’s highest office. She campaigned promising residents that she would aggressively tackle the city’s crime woes. nyti.ms/469dzlM
Voters in Ohio are set to decide whether to enshrine a right to abortion in its Constitution. Follow live results here, with almost 20% of votes reported. nyti.ms/46cgeve

Polls in states with major elections will close on Tuesday across a three-hour period across the U.S., beginning at 6 p.m. ET in Kentucky.

Here's when the first polls for local and statewide elections will close in certain states.

Donald Trump took the witness stand on Monday in a packed New York courtroom in his civil fraud trial that threatens the business empire that made his name. Here are five things we learned during his testimony.

It's impossible to predict exactly when election results will be available. But in these off-year races, with most polls closing between 7 and 8 p.m. ET, it’s not unreasonable to hope for results in a timely manner.

Here's when races may be called.

Barack Obama's aides in 2013 viewed Ron Dermer, Israel's ambassador to the U.S., as a right-wing political operative rather than a diplomat. He now sits in Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s war cabinet and is a chief liaison to the Biden administration.

Facing growing anger from their own people, Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt are intensifying their appeals to the U.S. to pressure Israel to implement an immediate cease-fire in Gaza or risk sabotaging the security of the entire Middle East.

A month after the attacks on Israel in which hundreds of heavily armed Hamas assailants surged across the border from Gaza, Israel has yet to declare an official day, or days, of mourning for the roughly 1,400 people killed in the assault.

The House moved closer to censuring Rep. Rashida Tlaib, Democrat of Michigan, putting lawmakers on track to formally rebuke the only Palestinian American in Congress for her statements regarding the Israel-Hamas war. A final vote is expected on Wednesday.

The U.S. Capitol Police arrested a man with a gun near the Capitol and Senate office buildings on Tuesday afternoon, putting Congress and the Capitol complex into a state of high alert as they also examined a suspicious package in the same area.
Cherelle Parker, a former City Council member, is poised to become the first woman to lead Philadelphia as America’s sixth-biggest city's mayor. Her to-do list is daunting.

Breaking News: American babies are born with syphilis in sharply increasing numbers, with the infection becoming more than ten times as common over the past decade, the CDC reported, calling the situation "dire."

More than eight in 10 Americans favor a federal ban on those convicted of domestic violence from purchasing a gun.

Though access to firearms has long been a topic of debate, the U.S. Supreme Court has broadly expanded the right to carry guns in public.

Prime Minister António Costa of Portugal resigned unexpectedly on Tuesday, hours after the police raided government buildings and issued an arrest warrant for his chief of staff. Prosecutors said the raids were part of an investigation into corruption.
The U.S. Supreme Court is hearing arguments on Tuesday on whether the government may disarm people subject to restraining orders for domestic abuse. Follow our live updates on the case.
A second Colorado police officer was acquitted in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a 23-year-old unarmed Black man.
The James Webb telescope forever changed our view of the universe and our past. Here’s a guide to what it shows.
Gunshot wounds are the leading cause of death for children and adolescents in America. Fatal or not, the damage they leave behind reverberates among survivors.

Narges Mohammadi, the imprisoned Iranian human rights activist who won this year’s Nobel Peace Prize, began a hunger strike on Monday, after she was denied hospital treatment for two blocked coronary arteries, her family said.

The U.S. State Dept. has approved a $320 million sale to Israel of equipment for kits that turn unguided bombs into more precise, GPS-guided munitions, according to a letter sent by the department to Congress that was obtained by The New York Times.

Voters in six key swing states — Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania — trust Donald Trump more than President Biden to manage the economy, according to the latest New York Times/Siena College polls. nyti.ms/3QMPWuS

The National Science Foundation watchdog is sending agents to a U.S. research base in Antarctica after a 2022 report raised concerns about sexual assault, sexual harassment and stalking in the program.

The Israel-Hamas war has led to “the highest number of United Nations fatalities ever recorded in a single conflict,” the leaders of major UN agencies and other humanitarian groups said, calling for an “immediate humanitarian cease-fire.” nyti.ms/3SuK0I9

In his civil fraud trial, Donald Trump assailed New York’s attorney general and the judge, who repeatedly tried to rein in his meandering testimony, saying at one point: “Irrelevant, irrelevant. Answer the question.”

Get the latest on Trump’s trial.

After at least two years by herself at the bottom of a Scottish cliff, Fiona the sheep was rescued on Saturday and brought to a farm, where she is set to live out the rest of her days. Some animal rights activists are concerned about her new home. nyti.ms/3QrEpjd
Here is a closer look at the scene inside the courtroom just before Donald Trump took the stand in his civil fraud trial on Monday. Follow live updates from our reporters. nyti.ms/3SwCHzI
Whitney Wolfe Herd, who founded the dating app Bumble a decade ago, is stepping down. She will be replaced by Lidiane Jones, the chief executive of Slack, the workplace-messaging platform.
Breaking News: The father of a man accused of killing seven people at a Fourth of July parade in suburban Chicago pleaded guilty to charges related to helping his son get a gun license.

Donald Trump's civil fraud trial stems from a lawsuit brought by New York's attorney general, which accuses Trump and other defendants of fraudulently inflating the value of assets to obtain favorable loans and insurance deals. Here's what to know.

Donald Trump’s testimony in his civil fraud trial on Monday will not be televised. Recordings of court proceedings in New York are typically prohibited, and no exception has been made for Trump. 

Follow our live updates.
Taylor Swift’s re-recording of her album ‘1989’ has now topped the first-week total of the original album from 2014. It was the biggest opening sales week of her career. nyti.ms/3seYuRY

Black voters are more disconnected from the Democratic Party than they have been in decades, frustrated with what many see as inaction on their political priorities and unhappy with President Biden, a candidate they helped lift to the White House.
Donald Trump is expected to take the stand Monday in his civil fraud trial, where his credibility, coherence and self-control will be tested.

Marathon Day is something of an unofficial holiday for New York City, as people come out with costumes, cow bells, live music and signs to support the runners. Our photographers captured the scenes across the city. Here are some of their photos. www.nytimes.com/live/2023/11...

Tamirat Tola broke the course record, Hellen Obiri won a dramatic victory and Catherine Debrunner and Marcel Hug set records in the wheelchair divisions. Here are highlights from the New York City Marathon. www.nytimes.com/live/2023/11...
More than 300 Americans and their families have been able to leave the war-ravaged Gaza Strip, a White House official said on Sunday, but negotiations over releasing American hostages remain tenuous.

Tens of thousands of demonstrators crowded the streets of U.S. cities on Saturday to denounce the scope and scale of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza in response to last month’s terrorist assault by Hamas. www.nytimes.com/2023/11/05/w...

Researchers discovered a new kind of mosasaur — a type of giant sea creature that lived alongside the dinosaurs — in North Dakota, scientists announced last week. Its name, Jormungandr walhallaensis, draws on Norse mythology.
Secretary of State Antony Blinken made a surprise visit to Baghdad after a similarly unannounced trip to the West Bank earlier today. Follow the latest updates.
Russian missiles struck a group of Ukrainian soldiers at an award ceremony in southern Ukraine, killing some and leaving others wounded, two senior Ukrainian military officials said Sunday.

Dozens of migrant farm workers from Thailand were seized or killed in the Oct. 7 raids on Israel. Their relatives are pleading for answers, saying they have received no communication from Thai or Israeli government officials.
Tyson Foods is recalling nearly 30,000 pounds of its dinosaur-shaped chicken nuggets after some consumers said they found small metal pieces in them, federal officials said.

The Israeli government is privately pushing for large numbers of Gazans to move to Egypt, diplomats say — fueling Palestinian fears that Israel is using the war to permanently displace the more than two million people living in Gaza.

An explosion overnight in a densely populated refugee camp in the central Gaza Strip destroyed several buildings and appeared to have killed and wounded many people, photos and videos from the scene on Sunday showed.

Many of the U.S. artillery troops sent to bombard the Islamic State returned home plagued by nightmares, panic attacks, depression and hallucinations, a New York Times investigation found. The military struggled to understand what was wrong.
The New York City Marathon winners are in: Hellen Obiri of Kenya won the women’s race, and Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia won the men’s race.

There aren’t many signs of the electoral strength that helped President Biden defeat Donald Trump in 2020, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls found. 

Nate Cohn explains the findings.
Catherine Debrunner of Switzerland won her first New York City Marathon wheelchair race in a time of 1:39:32, a course record.
Marcel Hug of Switzerland won his record sixth New York City wheelchair marathon in an unofficial time of 1:25:29, three seconds short of the course record he set last year.

A standoff that shut down the Hamburg airport ended on Sunday afternoon, nearly 18 hours after German authorities responded to an armed man who drove his vehicle onto the tarmac and parked near a plane.
How did you do in Connections today? Players must select four groups of four words without making more than four mistakes. www.nytimes.com/games/connec...
President Biden is trailing Donald Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 election, new polls by The New York Times and Siena College have found.

Airstrikes continued to pound Gaza City in proximity to hospitals and schools on Saturday, while Israel reiterated its order to civilians to leave northern Gaza as it intensifies its military operations on the ground there. Follow our live updates.

Whose idea was daylight saving time, anyway? The twice-yearly ritual has roots in cost-cutting strategies of the late 19th century.

Thousands of people are trapped in long-dead marriages in the Philippines, the only country in the world, besides the Vatican, where divorce is illegal. But a campaign framing it as a basic human right is picking up, despite systemic and religious barriers.

A former U.S. Marine who served in the Trump administration as an aide was sentenced to nearly six years in prison for his role in the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. Prosecutors said he used a stolen riot shield to repeatedly assault officers.

A big chunk of Hoboken, New Jersey, will be underwater by 2100, some scientists have forecast. But for more than a decade, the flood-prone city on the Hudson River has been trying to thwart fate — and it's making progress.

The Israeli military said it carried out an airstrike on an ambulance “being used by a Hamas terrorist cell” outside Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Friday. A hospital official said 13 people were killed.

Eric Adams has faced ethics issues for years, but the New York City mayor has not been implicated in any misconduct. Now a corruption investigation into whether his campaign conspired with the Turkish government to receive illegal donations poses a serious threat.

Eric Trump is testifying in a civil fraud case brought by New York’s attorney general in which his father is accused of inflating the value of his assets. The case threatens the Trump family’s business. Follow live updates.
Breaking News: The House voted to tie $14.3 billion in Israel aid to domestic spending cuts, defying President Biden’s veto threat and opposition in the Senate.

A false rumor that incited a violent mob in Dagestan on Sunday was shared online for longer and more widely than previously reported, a New York Times analysis found, showing the power and danger of disinformation in areas far from the Israel-Hamas war.
Steven Tyler of Aerosmith has been accused in a lawsuit of sexually assaulting a teenage girl in the 1970s for the second time in the past year.

Six Flags, an amusement park corporation, is merging with its rival Cedar Fair in an $8 billion deal, the two companies announced on Thursday. Together, they will operate 27 amusement parks, 15 water parks and nine resort properties in North America.

The Justice Department opened a far-reaching civil rights investigation of two troubled jails in South Carolina on Thursday after reports of violent and unhealthy living conditions, failure to treat mentally ill prisoners and the abuse of inmates by guards.

Skims is getting bedazzled. “I feel like it really embodies who I am, in being really simplistic, but then I have this full glitzy feminine side,” Kim Kardashian said of the collaboration with Swarovski. nyti.ms/45Xr3Rt
The New York Times asked all 50 states how they manage groundwater. The answers show why aquifers in the U.S. are in trouble.
International criticism of Israel’s war effort mounted on Thursday as Israeli forces ventured into Gaza City and extended their devastating bombing campaign in the Gaza Strip.
Israeli soldiers have entered Gaza City, the Israeli military said on Thursday, as they push forward with what officials have predicted will be a long ground invasion. Follow live updates.
Violence in the West Bank has worsened since the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks.

Bob Goldberg's resignation comes days after a $1.8 billion verdict against NAR and two months after The New York Times reported complaints of sexual harassment and discrimination from multiple women in the group.

Breaking News: The FBI searched the home of Mayor Eric Adams’s fund-raising chief, Brianna Suggs, who is deeply entwined in efforts to advance the New York City mayor’s agenda.

Taylor Tomlinson, 29, will take over the time slot after “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” on CBS. The move makes her not just the only woman on a late-night show on network television now, but also the youngest by two decades. nyti.ms/3SoM6sY
Breaking News: The U.S. will urge Israel to periodically pause its attacks on Gaza to allow hostages to be released and humanitarian aid to be distributed.

Videos and photos of the war between Israel and Hamas are competing with misappropriated depictions of unrelated tragedies. It's a common form of misinformation online, and a cycle that experts say diminishes the experiences of victims past and present.

Donald Trump Jr. has begun testifying in a civil fraud trial brought by New York’s attorney general in which his father is accused of inflating the value of his assets. He is the first of the Trump siblings to take the stand. Follow live updates.

President Zelensky of has expressed frustration over what he has labeled unrealistic expectations for rapid success on the battlefield amid concerns that slow progress against Russian forces will discourage Ukraine’s allies from sustaining military aid.

Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York announced on Tuesday up to $75 million in grants for local police departments and houses of worship in response to an uptick in reported antisemitic attacks and hate crimes against Palestinians in the wake of the Israel-Hamas war.

Breaking News: A group of home sellers won $1.8 billion after a jury found that brokerages conspired to artificially inflate real estate agents’ commissions. The decision has the potential to radically alter the home-buying process in the U.S.
Breaking News: Israel hit a dense Gaza neighborhood, saying it killed a ringleader of the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks. A nearby hospital said numerous people were killed. Follow our live coverage.

Israel has said its two military goals are to destroy Hamas and free the 240 hostages held in locations likely scattered around Gaza. Israel’s defense minister met with families of the victims, and insisted those two goals were not incompatible.

Under cross-examination, Sam Bankman-Fried denied knowing that billions of dollars in FTX customer money had been misappropriated until shortly before his crypto company collapsed last year. Here’s the latest on his criminal fraud trial.

Matthew Perry "laid bare his wounds, his struggles, his complicated relationship with drugs and alcohol. That’s the best we can do in life — be truthful and hope those truths become lanterns for others," writes Patti Davis in a guest essay.

Maine is facing intense scrutiny over its permissive gun laws following the mass shooting in Lewiston, where 18 people were killed on Oct. 25. Recent attempts to enact laws requiring universal background checks and waiting periods have failed.

The director of the New York office of the UN’s human rights agency has resigned. “We are seeing a genocide unfolding before our eyes, and the Organization that we serve appears powerless to stop it,” he wrote in a letter.

Dr. Michael Hayden has spent over a decade looking for the looted silver Judaica stolen from his grandparents, who were killed by the Nazis. His effort shows the dedication Jewish families have put toward reclaiming their relatives' items taken during WWII.
Iranian cyberattacks have moved beyond disrupting services to spying on Israel and others, according to a leading Israeli-American security firm.

That verbal style of rising uptalk by the actor Matthew Perry, who died on Saturday at 54, would become one of the show’s trademarks.
The Biden Administration on Tuesday approved a plan to install up to 176 giant wind turbines off the coast of Virginia. If completed, it would be the largest offshore wind farm in the U.S.

Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul, took the stand on Monday for the second time. The cross-examination exposed cracks in Bankman-Fried’s claims, dealing a potentially serious blow to his credibility with the jury.

Republicans, who have little power in California, have found traction in a handful of suburbs with gender identity policies in schools. It's a shift that has transformed politics at the school board level, spurred legal disputes and divided parents.

Africa has the fastest-growing, youngest population of any continent. By 2050, one in four people on the planet will be African — a development that will transform many African countries, experts say, and reshape their relationship with the world.

A Denver courtroom will host a trial, starting Monday, to determine whether Donald Trump is eligible to be president at all. Six Colorado voters, with the help of a watchdog group, argue Trump is ineligible to hold office under the 14th Amendment.

The Israeli military on Sunday signaled a heavier assault on Gaza, saying it was “gradually expanding the ground activity and the scope of our forces.” President Biden urged Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to protect civilians. Follow updates.

Israel's prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, apologized Sunday for accusing his military and security chiefs of lapses that led to the Hamas massacre, but didn't take responsibility himself. For many Israelis, it confirmed suspicions of governmental rifts.

Inna Vernikov, a Republican councilwoman from Brooklyn, was arrested and charged with criminal possession of a firearm after images were posted to social media of her carrying a gun on her waist at a pro-Palestinian rally Thursday at Brooklyn College.

The Biden administration plans to award up to $7 billion to create seven regional hubs around the U.S. that will make and use hydrogen, a clean-burning fuel, with the potential to power ships or factories without producing any planet-warming emissions.

Rep. Jim Jordan, the hard-right Republican who is the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, was poised on Friday to make another bid for House Speaker, toiling to unite the GOP after deposing Kevin McCarthy and blocking Rep. Steve Scalise.

This weekend, millions of people will feast their eyes on the latest celestial marvel: an annular solar eclipse gracing the skies of the Western Hemisphere. Here's what to know about the so-called “ring of fire.”

Six days of Israeli airstrikes have left more than 300,000 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip homeless, with two million residents facing critical shortages of food, water and fuel, while Israeli troops prepared on Thursday for a possible ground invasion after Hamas’s deadly weekend assault.

California has put a water-stressed farming region on notice for having “inadequate” plans to curb its overuse of groundwater, bringing officials closer to directly intervening, for the first time in state history, in the way growers manage their underground water supplies.

Seventeen deputies at a South Florida sheriff’s office were charged with defrauding federal loan programs of nearly half a million dollars intended to help businesses that were struggling during the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities said.

The Israeli airline El Al said it would fly on the Jewish Sabbath for the first time since 1982 to carry reservists, members of the security forces and medical teams to Israel. The company said it received religious approval to operate on the Sabbath.

A Black high school student in Texas who had been suspended because of how he wears his hair was removed from his school on Wednesday and transferred to a disciplinary school program, a letter from the school district shared by the student’s family said.

Donald Trump's lawyers lashed out at the special counsel, Jack Smith, on Wednesday, accusing his office of violating Trump's due process rights by seeking to obtain a guilty verdict against him before Election Day.
Two years after the federal government approved $350 billion in emergency funding for states and localities to respond to the public health crisis, much of the funds have not been used.

Luton Airport outside London said it suspended flights through at least midday Wednesday after a parking garage collapsed because of a fire overnight.

The fate of Donald Trump's flagship New York properties, the future of his business and $250 million. These are the stakes in Trump’s civil fraud trial, which began on Monday and is separate from his four criminal indictments.

“Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé” will be released in theaters on Dec. 1.

The concert film will track the tour’s journey from its opening in Stockholm in May to its finale in Kansas City, Missouri, on Oct. 1. nyti.ms/3rJeoDA
Bears are having a moment. Here's why they seem to be in the news and on TikTok more than ever before.
